1396878_11_ITEM1_P0_S0	The United States Gasoline Fund, LP ( UGA ) is a Delaware limited partnership organized on April 13, 2007.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P0_S1	UGA maintains its main business office at 1320 Harbor Bay Parkway, Suite 145, Alameda, California 94502.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P1_S0	UGA is a commodity pool that issues limited partnership interests ( units ) traded on the NYSE Arca, Inc. (the NYSE Arca ).
1396878_11_ITEM1_P2_S0	The investment objective of UGA is for the changes in percentage terms of its units net asset value ( NAV ) to reflect the changes in percentage terms of the spot price of gasoline (also known as reformulated gasoline blendstock for oxygen blending, or RBOB ) for delivery to the New York harbor, as measured by the changes in the price of the futures contract for gasoline traded on the New York Mercantile Exchange (the NYMEX ) that is the near month contract to expire, except when the near month contract is within two weeks of expiration, in which case the futures contract will be the next month contract to expire, less UGA s expenses.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P2_S1	UGA s units began trading on February 26, 2008.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P3_S0	USCF is the general partner of UGA and is responsible for the management of UGA.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P4_S0	USCF is a single member limited liability company that was formed in the state of Delaware on May 10, 2005.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P4_S1	Prior to June 13, 2008, USCF was known as Victoria Bay Asset Management, LLC.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P4_S2	It maintains its main business office at 1320 Harbor Bay Parkway, Suite 145, Alameda, California 94502.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P4_S3	USCF is a wholly-owned subsidiary of Wainwright Holdings, Inc., a Delaware corporation ( Wainwright ).
1396878_11_ITEM1_P4_S4	Mr. Nicholas Gerber (discussed below) controls Wainwright by virtue of his ownership of Wainwright s shares.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P4_S5	Wainwright previously owned an insurance company organized under Bermuda law, which has been liquidated, and a registered investment adviser firm named Ameristock Corporation, which has been distributed to the Wainwright shareholders.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P5_S0	USCF is a member of the National Futures Association (the NFA ) and registered as a commodity pool operator ( CPO ) with the Commodity Futures Trading Commission (the CFTC ) on December 1, 2005.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P6_S0	On May 12, 2005, USCF formed the United States Oil Fund, LP ( USOF ), another limited partnership that is a commodity pool and issues units traded on the NYSE Arca.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P6_S1	The investment objective of USOF is for the changes in percentage terms of its units NAV to reflect the changes in percentage terms of the spot price of light, sweet crude oil delivered to Cushing, Oklahoma, as measured by the changes in the price of the futures contract for light, sweet crude oil traded on the NYMEX that is the near month contract to expire, except when the near month contract is within two weeks of expiration, in which case it will be measured by the futures contract that is the next month contract to expire, less USOF s expenses.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P6_S2	USOF s units began trading on April 10, 2006.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P7_S0	USCF is the general partner of USOF and is responsible for the management of USOF.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P8_S0	On September 11, 2006, USCF formed the United States Natural Gas Fund, LP ( USNG ), another limited partnership that is a commodity pool and issues units traded on the NYSE Arca.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P8_S1	The investment objective of USNG is for the changes in percentage terms of its units NAV to reflect the changes in percentage terms of the spot price of natural gas delivered at the Henry Hub, Louisiana, as measured by the changes in the price of the futures contract on natural gas traded on the NYMEX that is the near month contract to expire, except when the near month contract is within two weeks of expiration, in which case it will be measured by the futures contract that is the next month contract to expire, less USNG s expenses.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P8_S2	USNG s units began trading on April 18, 2007.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P9_S0	USCF is the general partner of USNG and is responsible for the management of USNG.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P10_S0	On June 27, 2007, USCF formed the United States 12 Month Oil Fund, LP ( US12OF ), also a limited partnership that is a commodity pool and issues units traded on the NYSE Arca.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P10_S1	The investment objective of US12OF is for the changes in percentage terms of its units NAV to reflect the changes in percentage terms of the spot price of light, sweet crude oil delivered to Cushing, Oklahoma, as measured by the changes in the average of the prices of 12 futures contracts on light, sweet crude oil traded on the NYMEX, consisting of the near month contract to expire and the contracts for the following 11 months, for a total of 12 consecutive months contracts, except when the near month contract is within two weeks of expiration, in which case it will be measured by the futures contracts that are the next month contract to expire and the contracts for the following 11 consecutive months, less US12OF s expenses.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P11_S0	When calculating the daily movement of the average price of the 12 contracts, each contract month will be equally weighted.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P12_S0	US12OF s units began trading on December 6, 2007.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P13_S0	USCF is the general partner of US12OF and is responsible for the management of US12OF.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P14_S0	On April 13, 2007, USCF formed the United States Heating Oil Fund, LP ( USHO ), also a limited partnership that is a commodity pool and issues units traded on the NYSE Arca.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P14_S1	The investment objective of USHO is for the changes in percentage terms of its units NAV to reflect the changes in percentage terms of the spot price of heating oil (also known as No. 2 fuel oil) delivered to the New York harbor, as measured by the changes in the price of the futures contract on heating oil traded on the NYMEX that is the near month contract to expire, except when the near month contract is within two weeks of expiration, in which case it will be measured by the futures contract that is the next month contract to expire, less USHO s expenses.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P14_S2	USHO s units began trading on April 9, 2008.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P15_S0	USCF is the general partner of USHO and is responsible for the management of USHO.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P16_S0	On June 30, 2008, USCF formed the United States Short Oil Fund, LP ( USSO ), also a limited partnership that is a commodity pool and issues units traded on the NYSE Arca.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P16_S1	The investment objective of USSO is for the changes in percentage terms of its units NAV to inversely reflect the changes in percentage terms of the spot price of light, sweet crude oil delivered to Cushing, Oklahoma, as measured by the changes in the price of the futures contract on light, sweet crude oil traded on the NYMEX that is the near month contract to expire, except when the near month contract is within two weeks of expiration, in which case it will be measured by the futures contract that is the next month contract to expire, less USSO s expenses.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P16_S2	USSO s units began trading on September 24, 2009.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P17_S0	USCF is the general partner of USSO and is responsible for the management of USSO.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P18_S0	On June 27, 2007, USCF formed the United States 12 Month Natural Gas Fund, LP ( US12NG ), also a limited partnership that is a commodity pool and issues units traded on the NYSE Arca.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P18_S1	The investment objective of US12NG is for the changes in percentage terms of its units NAV to reflect the changes in percentage terms of the spot price of natural gas delivered at the Henry Hub, Louisiana, as measured by the changes in the average of the prices of 12 futures contracts on natural gas traded on the NYMEX, consisting of the near month contract to expire and the contracts for the following 11 months, for a total of 12 consecutive months contracts except when the near month contract is within two weeks of expiration, in which case it will be measured by the futures contracts that are the next month contract to expire and the contracts for the following 11 consecutive months, less US12NG s expenses.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P19_S0	When calculating the daily movement of the average price of the 12 contracts, each contract month will be equally weighted.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P20_S0	US12NG s units began trading on November 18, 2009.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P21_S0	USCF is the general partner of US12NG and is responsible for the management of US12NG.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P22_S0	On September 2, 2009, USCF formed the United States Brent Oil Fund, LP ( USBO ), also a limited partnership that is a commodity pool and issues units traded on the NYSE Arca.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P22_S1	The investment objective of USBO is for the daily changes in percentage terms of its units NAV to reflect the daily changes in percentage terms of the spot price of Brent crude oil, as measured by the changes in the price of the futures contract on Brent crude oil traded on the ICE Futures Exchange (the ICE Futures ) that is the near month contract to expire, except when the near month contract is within two weeks of expiration, in which case it will be measured by the futures contract that is the next month contract to expire, less USBO s expenses.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P22_S2	USBO s units began trading on June 2, 2010.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P23_S0	USCF is the general partner of USBO and is responsible for the management of USBO.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P24_S0	On April 1, 2010, USCF, in its role as sponsor, formed the United States Commodity Index Fund ( USCI ), as a series of the United States Commodity Index Funds Trust, a Delaware statutory trust (the Trust ).
1396878_11_ITEM1_P24_S1	USCI is a commodity pool and issues units traded on the NYSE Arca.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P24_S2	The investment objective of USCI is for the daily changes in percentage terms of its units NAV to reflect the daily changes in percentage terms of the SummerHaven Dynamic Commodity Index Total Return (the Commodity Index ), less USCI s expenses.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P24_S3	USCI s units began trading on August 10, 2010.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P25_S0	USCF is the sponsor of USCI and is responsible for the management of USCI.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P26_S0	USOF, USNG, US12OF, USHO, USSO, US12NG, USBO and USCI are collectively referred to herein as the Related Public Funds .
1396878_11_ITEM1_P26_S1	For more information about each of the Related Public Funds, investors in UGA may call 1-800-920-0259 or go online to www.unitedstatescommodityfunds.com.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P27_S0	USCF has filed a registration statement for three other exchange-traded security funds, the United States Metals Index Fund ( USMI ), the United States Agriculture Index Fund ( USAI ) and the United States Copper Index Fund ( USCUI ), each of which is a series of the Trust.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P27_S1	The investment objective of USMI will be for the daily changes in percentage terms of its units NAV to reflect the daily changes in percentage terms of the SummerHaven Dynamic Metals Index Total Return (the Metals Index ), less USMI s expenses.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P27_S2	The investment objective of USAI will be for the daily changes in percentage terms of its units NAV to reflect the daily changes in percentage terms of the SummerHaven Dynamic Agriculture Index Total Return (the Agriculture Index ), less USAI s expenses.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P27_S3	The investment objective of USCUI will be for the daily changes in percentage terms of its units NAV to reflect the daily changes in percentage terms of the SummerHaven Copper Index Total Return (the Copper Index ), less USCUI s expenses.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P28_S0	USCF is required to evaluate the credit risk of UGA to the futures commission merchant, oversee the purchase and sale of UGA s units by certain authorized purchasers ( Authorized Purchasers ), review daily positions and margin requirements of UGA and manage UGA s investments.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P28_S1	USCF also pays the fees of ALPS Distributors, Inc., which serves as the marketing agent for UGA (the Marketing Agent ), and Brown Brothers Harriman Co. ( BBH Co. ), which serves as the administrator (the Administrator ) and the custodian (the Custodian ) for UGA.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P29_S0	Limited partners have no right to elect USCF as the general partner on an annual or any other continuing basis.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P29_S1	If USCF voluntarily withdraws as general partner, however, the holders of a majority of UGA s outstanding units (excluding for purposes of such determination units owned, if any, by the withdrawing USCF and its affiliates) may elect its successor.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P29_S2	USCF may not be removed as general partner except upon approval by the affirmative vote of the holders of at least 66 and 2/3 percent of UGA s outstanding units (excluding units owned, if any, by USCF and its affiliates), subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions set forth in the LP Agreement.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P30_S0	The business and affairs of USCF are managed by a board of directors (the Board ), which is comprised of four management directors, some of whom are also its executive officers (the Management Directors ), and three independent directors who meet the independent director requirements established by the NYSE Arca and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended (the Exchange Act ).
1396878_11_ITEM1_P30_S1	Notwithstanding the foregoing, the Management Directors have the authority to manage USCF pursuant to its limited liability company agreement, as amended from time to time.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P31_S0	Through its Management Directors, USCF manages the day-to-day operations of UGA.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P31_S1	The Board has an audit committee which is made up of the three independent directors (Peter M. Robinson, Gordon L. Ellis and Malcolm R. Fobes III).
1396878_11_ITEM1_P31_S2	For additional information relating to the audit committee, please see Item 10.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P32_S0	Directors, Executive Officers and Corporate Governance Audit Committee in this annual report on Form 10-K.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P33_S0	The net assets of UGA consist primarily of investments in futures contracts for gasoline, but may also consist of investment contracts for other types of gasoline, crude oil, heating oil, natural gas and other petroleum-based fuels that are traded on the NYMEX, ICE Futures or other U.S. and foreign exchanges (collectively, Futures Contracts ).
1396878_11_ITEM1_P33_S1	UGA may also invest in other gasoline-related investments such as cash-settled options on Futures Contracts, forward contracts for gasoline, cleared swap contracts and over-the-counter transactions that are based on the price of gasoline, crude oil and other petroleum-based fuels, Futures Contracts and indices based on the foregoing (collectively, Other Gasoline-Related Investments ).
1396878_11_ITEM1_P33_S2	For convenience and unless otherwise specified, Futures Contracts and Other Gasoline-Related Investments collectively are referred to as Gasoline Interests in this annual report on Form 10-K. UGA invests in Gasoline Interests to the fullest extent possible without being leveraged or unable to satisfy its current or potential margin or collateral obligations with respect to its investments in Futures Contracts and Other Gasoline-Related Investments.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P33_S3	In pursuing this objective, the primary focus of USCF is the investment in Futures Contracts and the management of UGA s investments in short-term obligations of the United States of two years or less ( Treasuries ), cash and/or cash equivalents for margining purposes and as collateral.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P34_S0	The investment objective of UGA is for the changes in percentage terms of its units NAV to reflect the changes in percentage terms of the spot price of gasoline, as measured by the changes in the price of the futures contract on gasoline (also known as RBOB), for delivery to the New York harbor, traded on the NYMEX that is the near month contract to expire, except when the near month contract is within two weeks of expiration, in which case the futures contract will be the next month contract to expire, less UGA s expenses.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P34_S1	It is not the intent of UGA to be operated in a fashion such that its NAV will equal, in dollar terms, the spot price of gasoline or any particular futures contract based on gasoline.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P35_S0	UGA seeks to achieve its investment objective by investing in a mix of Futures Contracts and Other Gasoline-Related Investments such that the changes in its NAV will closely track the changes in the price of the NYMEX futures contract for gasoline delivered to the New York harbor (the Benchmark Futures Contract ).
1396878_11_ITEM1_P35_S1	USCF believes changes in the price of the Benchmark Futures Contract have historically exhibited a close correlation with the changes in the spot price of gasoline.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P36_S0	On any valuation day (a valuation day is any NYSE Arca trading day as of which UGA calculates its NAV as described herein), the Benchmark Futures Contract is the near month contract for gasoline traded on the NYMEX unless the near month contract will expire within two weeks of the valuation day, in which case the Benchmark Futures Contract is the next month contract for gasoline traded on the NYMEX.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P37_S0	As a specific benchmark, USCF endeavors to place UGA s trades in Futures Contracts and Other Gasoline-Related Investments and otherwise manage UGA s investments so that A will be within plus/minus 10 percent of B, where:
1396878_11_ITEM1_P38_S0	B is the average daily change in the price of the Benchmark Futures Contract over the same period.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P39_S0	USCF believes that market arbitrage opportunities cause daily changes in UGA s unit price on the NYSE Arca to closely track daily changes in UGA s NAV per unit.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P39_S1	USCF further believes that the daily changes in prices of the Benchmark Futures Contract have historically closely tracked the daily changes in the spot price of gasoline.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P39_S2	USCF believes that the net effect of these two relationships and the expected relationship described above between UGA s NAV and the Benchmark Futures Contract will be that the daily changes in the price of UGA s units on the NYSE Arca will continue to closely track the daily changes in the spot price of gasoline, less UGA s expenses.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P40_S0	An investment in the units provides a means for diversifying an investor s portfolio or hedging exposure to changes in gasoline prices.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P40_S1	An investment in the units allows both retail and institutional investors to easily gain this exposure to the gasoline market in a transparent, cost-effective manner.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P41_S0	The expected correlation of the price of UGA s units, UGA s NAV and the price of the Benchmark Futures Contract is illustrated in the following diagram:
1396878_11_ITEM1_P42_S0	USCF employs a neutral investment strategy intended to track changes in the price of the Benchmark Futures Contract regardless of whether the price goes up or goes down.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P42_S1	UGA s neutral investment strategy is designed to permit investors generally to purchase and sell UGA s units for the purpose of investing indirectly in gasoline in a cost-effective manner, and/or to permit participants in the gasoline or other industries to hedge the risk of losses in their gasoline-related transactions.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P42_S2	Accordingly, depending on the investment objective of an individual investor, the risks generally associated with investing in gasoline and/or the risks involved in hedging may exist.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P42_S3	In addition, an investment in UGA involves the risk that the changes in the price of UGA s units will not accurately track the changes in the Benchmark Futures Contract.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P43_S0	The Benchmark Futures Contract is changed from the near month contract to expire to the next month contract to expire during one day each month.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P43_S1	On that day, USCF closes or sells UGA s Gasoline Interests and also reinvests or rolls in new Gasoline Interests.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P44_S0	The anticipated monthly dates on which the Benchmark Futures Contracts will be changed and UGA s Gasoline Interests will be rolled in 2011 are posted on UGA s website at www.unitedstatesgasolinefund.com, and are subject to change without notice.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P45_S0	UGA s total portfolio composition is disclosed on its website each day that the NYSE Arca is open for trading.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P45_S1	The website disclosure of portfolio holdings is made daily and includes, as applicable, the name and value of each Gasoline Interest, the specific types of Other Gasoline-Related Investments and characteristics of such Other Gasoline-Related Investments, Treasuries and amount of cash and/or cash equivalents held in UGA s portfolio.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P45_S2	UGA s website is publicly accessible at no charge.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P46_S0	UGA s assets are held in segregated accounts pursuant to the Commodity Exchange Act (the CEA ) and CFTC regulations.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P47_S0	The units issued by UGA may only be purchased by Authorized Purchasers and only in blocks of 100,000 units called Creation Baskets.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P47_S1	The amount of the purchase payment for a Creation Basket is equal to the aggregate NAV of the units in the Creation Basket.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P47_S2	Similarly, only Authorized Purchasers may redeem units and only in blocks of 100,000 units called Redemption Baskets.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P47_S3	The purchase price for Creation Baskets, and the redemption price for Redemption Baskets, is the actual NAV of the units purchased or redeemed calculated at the end of the business day when notice for a purchase or redemption is received by UGA.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P47_S4	In addition, Authorized Purchasers pay UGA a $1,000 fee for each order placed to create one or more Creation Baskets or redeem one or more Redemption Baskets.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P48_S0	The NYSE Arca publishes an approximate NAV intra-day based on the prior day s NAV and the current price of the Benchmark Futures Contract, but the basket price is determined based on the actual NAV at the end of the day.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P49_S0	While UGA issues units only in Creation Baskets, units may also be purchased and sold in much smaller increments on the NYSE Arca.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P49_S1	These transactions, however, are effected at the bid and ask prices established by specialist firm(s).
1396878_11_ITEM1_P49_S2	Like any listed security, units can be purchased and sold at any time a secondary market is open.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P50_S0	In managing UGA s assets, USCF does not use a technical trading system that issues buy and sell orders.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P50_S1	USCF instead employs a quantitative methodology whereby each time a Creation Basket is sold, USCF purchases Gasoline Interests, such as the Benchmark Futures Contract, that have an aggregate market value that approximates the amount of Treasuries and/or cash received upon the issuance of the Creation Basket.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P51_S0	As an example, assume that a Creation Basket is sold by UGA, and that UGA s closing NAV per unit is $50.00.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P51_S1	In that case, UGA would receive $5,000,000 in proceeds from the sale of the Creation Basket ($50.00 NAV per unit multiplied by 100,000 units, and excluding the Creation Basket fee of $1,000).
1396878_11_ITEM1_P51_S2	If one were to assume further that USCF wants to invest the entire proceeds from the Creation Basket in the Benchmark Futures Contract and that the market value of the Benchmark Futures Contract is $59,950, UGA would be unable to buy the exact number of Benchmark Futures Contracts with an aggregate market value equal to $5,000,000.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P51_S3	Instead, UGA would be able to purchase 83 Benchmark Futures Contracts with an aggregate market value of $4,975,850.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P51_S4	Assuming a margin requirement equal to 10% of the value of the Benchmark Futures Contract, UGA would be required to deposit $497,585 in Treasuries and cash with the futures commission merchant through which the Benchmark Futures Contracts were purchased.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P51_S5	The remainder of the proceeds from the sale of the Creation Basket, $4,502,415, would remain invested in cash, cash equivalents, and Treasuries as determined by USCF from time to time based on factors such as potential calls for margin or anticipated redemptions.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P52_S0	The specific Futures Contracts purchased depends on various factors, including a judgment by USCF as to the appropriate diversification of UGA s investments in futures contracts with respect to the month of expiration, and the prevailing price volatility of particular contracts.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P52_S1	While USCF has made significant investments in NYMEX Futures Contracts, as UGA reaches certain accountability levels or position limits on the NYMEX, or for other reasons, it may invest in Futures Contracts traded on other exchanges or may invest in Other Gasoline-Related Investments such as contracts in the over-the-counter market.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P53_S0	USCF does not anticipate letting UGA s Futures Contracts expire and taking delivery of the underlying commodity.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P53_S1	Instead, USCF closes existing positions, e.g. , when it changes the Benchmark Futures Contract or it otherwise determines it would be appropriate to do so and reinvests the proceeds in new Futures Contracts or Other Gasoline-Related Investments.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P53_S2	Positions may also be closed out to meet orders for Redemption Baskets and in such case proceeds for such baskets will not be reinvested.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P54_S0	By remaining invested as fully as possible in Futures Contracts or Other Gasoline-Related Investments, USCF believes that the changes in percentage terms in UGA s NAV will continue to closely track the changes in percentage terms in the prices of the Benchmark Futures Contract.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P55_S0	USCF believes that certain arbitrage opportunities result in the price of the units traded on the NYSE Arca closely tracking the NAV of UGA.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P55_S1	Additionally, futures contracts traded on the NYMEX have closely tracked the spot price of gasoline for delivery to the New York harbor.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P55_S2	Based on these expected interrelationships, USCF believes that the changes in the price of UGA s units traded on the NYSE Arca have closely tracked and will continue to closely track the changes in the spot price of gasoline.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P55_S3	For performance data relating to UGA s ability to track its benchmark, see Item 7.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P55_S4	Tracking UGA s Benchmark in this annual report on Form 10-K.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P56_S0	In a Futures Contract, one party agrees to buy a commodity such as gasoline from the other party at a later date at a price and quantity agreed-upon when the contract is made.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P56_S1	Futures Contracts are traded on futures exchanges, including the NYMEX.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P56_S2	For example, the Benchmark Futures Contract is traded on the NYMEX in units of 42,000 gallons (1,000 barrels).
1396878_11_ITEM1_P56_S3	The price of gasoline futures contracts on the NYMEX are priced by floor brokers and other exchange members both through an open outcry of offers to purchase or sell the contracts and through an electronic, screen-based system that determines the price by matching electronically offers to purchase and sell.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P57_S0	Certain typical and significant characteristics of Futures Contracts are discussed below.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P57_S1	Additional risks of investing in Futures Contracts are included in Item 1A. Risk Factors in this annual report on Form 10-K.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P58_S0	Impact of Accountability Levels, Position Limits and Price Fluctuation Limits .
1396878_11_ITEM1_P59_S0	Futures Contracts include typical and significant characteristics.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P59_S1	Most significantly, the CFTC and U.S. designated contract markets such as the NYMEX have established accountability levels and position limits on the maximum net long or net short futures contracts in commodity interests that any person or group of persons under common trading control (other than as a hedge, which an investment by UGA is not) may hold, own or control.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P60_S0	The net position is the difference between an individual or firm s open long contracts and open short contracts in any one commodity.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P60_S1	In addition, most U.S. futures exchanges, such as the NYMEX, limit the daily price fluctuation for Futures Contracts.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P60_S2	Currently, the ICE Futures imposes position and accountability limits that are similar to those imposed by the NYMEX but does not limit the maximum daily price fluctuation.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P61_S0	The accountability levels for the Benchmark Futures Contract and other Futures Contracts traded on the NYMEX are not a fixed ceiling, but rather a threshold above which the NYMEX may exercise greater scrutiny and control over an investor s positions.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P61_S1	The current accountability level for any one month in the Benchmark Futures Contract is 5,000 net contracts.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P61_S2	In addition, the NYMEX imposes an accountability level for all months of 7,000 net futures contracts for investments in futures contracts for gasoline.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P61_S3	If UGA and the Related Public Funds exceed these accountability levels for investments in the futures contract for gasoline, the NYMEX will monitor UGA s and the Related Public Funds exposure and ask for further information on their activities, including the total size of all positions, investment and trading strategy, and the extent of liquidity resources of UGA and the Related Public Funds.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P61_S4	If deemed necessary by the NYMEX, it could also order UGA and the Related Public Funds to reduce their aggregate net position back to the accountability level.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P61_S5	In addition, the ICE Futures maintains the same accountability levels, position limits and monitoring authority for its gasoline contract as the NYMEX.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P62_S0	As of December 31, 2010, UGA held a net of 660 NYMEX RBOB Gasoline Futures RB contracts and the Related Public Funds held 74 NYMEX RBOB Gasoline Futures XB contracts.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P62_S1	As of December 31, 2010, UGA did not hold any Futures Contracts traded on the ICE Futures.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P63_S0	If the NYMEX or the ICE Futures orders UGA to reduce its position back to the accountability level, or to an accountability level that the NYMEX or the ICE Futures deems appropriate for UGA, such an accountability level may impact the mix of investments in Gasoline Interests made by UGA.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P64_S0	To illustrate, assume that the price of the Benchmark Futures Contract was $2, the unit price of UGA is $10, and that the NYMEX has determined that UGA may not own more than 10,000 Benchmark Futures Contracts.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P64_S1	In such case, UGA could invest up to $840 million of its daily net assets in the Benchmark Futures Contract ( i.e. , $2 per contract multiplied by 42,000 (a Benchmark Futures Contract is a contract for 42,000 gallons (1,000 barrels) multiplied by 10,000 contracts)) before reaching the accountability level imposed by the NYMEX.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P64_S2	Once the daily net assets of the portfolio exceed $840 million in the Benchmark Futures Contract, the portfolio may not be able to make any further investments in the Benchmark Futures Contract.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P64_S3	If the NYMEX were to impose limits at the $840 million level (or another level), UGA anticipates that it would invest the majority of its assets above that level in a mix of other Futures Contracts or Other Gasoline-Related Investments in order to meet its investment objective.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P65_S0	See Item 1A. Risk Factors Risks Associated With Investing Directly or Indirectly in Gasoline Regulation of the commodity interests and energy markets is extensive and constantly changing; future regulatory developments are impossible to predict but may significantly and adversely affect UGA in this annual report on Form 10-K.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P66_S0	In addition to accountability levels, the NYMEX and the ICE Futures impose position limits on contracts held in the last few days of trading in the near month contract to expire.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P66_S1	It is unlikely that UGA will run up against such position limits because UGA s investment strategy is to close out its positions and roll from the near month contract to expire to the next month contract beginning two weeks from expiration of the contract.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P67_S0	U.S. futures exchanges, including the NYMEX, also limit the amount of price fluctuation for Futures Contracts.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P67_S1	For example, the NYMEX imposes a $0.25 per gallon ($10,500 per contract) price fluctuation limit for the Benchmark Futures Contract.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P67_S2	This limit is initially based off the previous trading day s settlement price.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P67_S3	If any Benchmark Futures Contract is traded, bid, or offered at the limit for five minutes, trading is halted for five minutes.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P67_S4	When trading resumes it begins at the point where the limit was imposed and the limit is reset to be $0.25 per gallon in either direction of that point.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P67_S5	If another halt were triggered, the market would continue to be expanded by $0.25 per gallon in either direction after each successive five-minute trading halt.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P67_S6	There is no maximum price fluctuation limit during any one trading session.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P68_S0	Currently, U.S. futures exchanges, including the NYMEX, do not implement fixed position limits for futures contracts held outside of the last few days of trading in the near month contract to expire.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P68_S1	However, the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (the Dodd-Frank Act ) which was signed into law on July 21, 2010, requires the CFTC to establish aggregate position limits that apply to both cleared and uncleared commodity swaps in addition to exchange-traded futures contracts held by an entity and certain of its affiliates.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P68_S2	Such position limits could limit UGA s ability to invest in accordance with its investment objective.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P69_S0	On January 13, 2011, the CFTC proposed new rules, which, if implemented in their proposed form, would establish position limits and limit formulas for certain commodity futures, including Futures Contracts and options on Futures Contracts, executed pursuant to the rules of designated contract markets ( i.e., certain regulated exchanges) and commodity swaps that are economically equivalent to such futures and options contracts.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P69_S1	The CFTC has also proposed aggregate position limits that would apply across different trading venues to contracts based on the same underlying commodity.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P69_S2	At this time, it is unknown precisely when such position limits would take effect.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P69_S3	The CFTC s position limits for futures contracts held during the last few days of trading in the near month contract to expire, which, under the CFTC s proposed rule would be substantially similar to the position limits currently set by the exchanges, could take effect as early as March 2011.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P69_S4	Based on the CFTC s current proposal, other position limits would not take effect until March 2012 or later.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P69_S5	The effect of this future regulatory change on UGA is impossible to predict, but it could be substantial and adverse.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P70_S0	UGA anticipates that to the extent it invests in Futures Contracts other than gasoline contracts (such as futures contracts for crude oil, natural gas, and other petroleum-based fuels) and Other Gasoline-Related Investments, it will enter into various non-exchange-traded derivative contracts to hedge the short-term price movements of such Futures Contracts and Other Gasoline-Related Investments against the current Benchmark Futures Contract.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P71_S0	Examples of the position and price limits currently imposed are as follows:
1396878_11_ITEM1_P72_S0	Any one month: 5,000 net futures / all months: 7,000 net futures, but not to exceed 1,000 contracts in the last three days of trading in the spot month.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P73_S0	$0.25 per gallon ($10,500 per contract) for all months.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P73_S1	If any contract is traded, bid, or offered at the limit for five minutes, trading is halted for five minutes.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P73_S2	When trading resumes, the limit is expanded by $0.25 per gallon in either direction.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P73_S3	If another halt were triggered, the market would continue to be expanded by $0.25 per gallon in either direction after each successive five-minute trading halt.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P73_S4	There will be no maximum price fluctuation limits during any one trading session.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P74_S0	Any one month: 7,000 net futures / all months: 7,000 net futures, but not to exceed 1,000 contracts in the last three days of trading in the spot month.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P75_S0	There is no maximum daily price fluctuation limit.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P76_S0	Any one month: 10,000 net futures / all months: 20,000 net futures, but not to exceed 3,000 contracts in the last three days of trading in the spot month.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P77_S0	$10.00 per barrel ($10,000 per contract) for all months.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P77_S1	If any contract is traded, bid, or offered at the limit for five minutes, trading is halted for five minutes.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P77_S2	When trading resumes, the limit is expanded by $10.00 per barrel in either direction.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P77_S3	If another halt were triggered, the market would continue to be expanded by $10.00 per barrel in either direction after each successive five-minute trading halt.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P77_S4	There will be no maximum price fluctuation limits during any one trading session.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P78_S0	Any one month: 20,000 net futures / all months: 20,000 net futures, but not to exceed 2,000 contracts in the last three days of trading in the spot month.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P79_S0	There is no maximum daily price fluctuation limit.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P80_S0	Any one month: 5,000 net futures / all months: 7,000 net futures, but not to exceed 1,000 contracts in the last three days of trading in the spot month.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P81_S0	$0.25 per gallon ($10,500 per contract) for all months.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P81_S1	If any contract is traded, bid, or offered at the limit for five minutes, trading is halted for five minutes.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P81_S2	When trading resumes, the limit is expanded by $0.25 per gallon in either direction.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P81_S3	If another halt were triggered, the market would continue to be expanded by $0.25 per gallon in either direction after each successive five-minute trading halt.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P81_S4	There will be no maximum price fluctuation limits during any one trading session.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P82_S0	Any one month: 6,000 net futures / all months: 12,000 net futures, but not to exceed 1,000 contracts in the last three days of trading in the spot month.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P83_S0	$3.00 per million British thermal units ( mmBtu ) ($30,000 per contract) for all months.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P83_S1	If any contract is traded, bid, or offered at the limit for five minutes, trading is halted for five minutes.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P83_S2	When trading resumes, the limit is expanded by $3.00 per mmBtu in either direction.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P83_S3	If another halt were triggered, the market would continue to be expanded by $3.00 per mmBtu in either direction after each successive five-minute trading halt.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P83_S4	There will be no maximum price fluctuation limits during any one trading session.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P84_S0	Any one month: 6,000 net futures / all months: 12,000 net futures, but not to exceed 1,000 contracts in the last three days of trading in the spot month.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P85_S0	There is no maximum daily price fluctuation limit.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P86_S0	There is no maximum daily price fluctuation limit.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P87_S0	Any one month: 10,000 net futures / all months: 20,000 net futures, but not to exceed 3,000 contracts in the last three days of trading in the spot month.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P88_S0	There is no maximum daily price fluctuation limit.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P89_S0	Despite daily price limits, the price volatility of Futures Contracts generally has been historically greater than that for traditional securities such as stocks and bonds.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P89_S1	Price volatility often is greater day-to-day as opposed to intra-day.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P89_S2	Futures Contracts tend to be more volatile than stocks and bonds because price movements for gasoline are more currently and directly influenced by economic factors for which current data is available and are traded by gasoline futures traders throughout the day.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P89_S3	These economic factors include changes in interest rates; governmental, agricultural, trade, fiscal, monetary and exchange control programs and policies; weather and climate conditions; changing supply and demand relationships; changes in balances of payments and trade; U.S. and international rates of inflation; currency devaluations and revaluations; U.S. and international political and economic events; and changes in philosophies and emotions of market participants.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P90_S0	Because UGA invests a significant portion of its assets in Futures Contracts, the assets of UGA, and therefore the prices of UGA units, may be subject to greater volatility than traditional securities.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P91_S0	Futures Contracts are marked to market at the end of each trading day and the margin required with respect to such contracts is adjusted accordingly.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P91_S1	This process of marking-to-market is designed to prevent losses from accumulating in any futures account.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P91_S2	Therefore, if UGA s futures positions have declined in value, UGA may be required to post additional variation margin to cover this decline.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P91_S3	Alternatively, if UGA futures positions have increased in value, this increase will be credited to UGA s account.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P92_S0	UGA may purchase Futures Contracts traded on the NYMEX that are based on gasoline.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P92_S1	The ICE Futures also offers an RBOB Gasoline Futures Contract which trades in units of 42,000 U.S. gallons (1,000 barrels).
1396878_11_ITEM1_P92_S2	The RBOB Gasoline Futures Contract is cash settled against the prevailing market price for RBOB gasoline in the New York harbor.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P92_S3	It may also purchase contracts on other exchanges, including the ICE Futures, the Singapore Exchange and the Dubai Mercantile Exchange.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P93_S0	Gasoline is the largest single volume refined product sold in the U.S. and accounts for almost half of national oil consumption.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P93_S1	The gasoline futures contract listed and traded on the NYMEX trades in units of 42,000 gallons (1,000 barrels) and is based on delivery at petroleum products terminals in the New York harbor, the major East Coast trading center for imports and domestic shipments from refineries in the New York harbor area or from the Gulf Coast refining centers.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P94_S0	The price of gasoline has historically been volatile.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P95_S0	In 2005, the NYMEX introduced new physical specifications for unleaded gasoline contracts to reflect the changes in the national standards for such fuels.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P95_S1	Unleaded gasoline using MTBE was being phased out and replaced with unleaded gasoline using ethanol.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P95_S2	As a result, NYMEX introduced a new gasoline futures contract in 2005.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P95_S3	The new futures contract trades under the ticker symbol RB .
1396878_11_ITEM1_P96_S0	The pre-existing unleaded gasoline futures contract, ticker symbol HU , ceased trading on December 29th, 2006.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P96_S1	For a period of approximately 15 months both contracts were traded on the NYMEX.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P97_S0	Crude oil is the world s most actively traded commodity.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P97_S1	The futures contracts for light, sweet crude oil that are traded on the NYMEX are the world s most liquid forum for crude oil trading, as well as the world s largest volume futures contract trading on a physical commodity.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P97_S2	Due to the liquidity and price transparency of oil futures contracts, they are used as a principal international pricing benchmark.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P97_S3	The futures contracts for light, sweet crude oil trade on the NYMEX in units of 1,000 U.S. barrels (42,000 gallons) and, if not closed out before maturity, will result in delivery of oil to Cushing, Oklahoma, which is also accessible to the international spot markets via pipelines.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P98_S0	In Europe, Brent crude oil is the standard for futures contracts and is primarily traded on the ICE Futures.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P99_S0	Brent crude oil is the price reference for two-thirds of the world s traded oil.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P100_S0	The ICE Brent Futures is a deliverable contract with an option to cash settle which trades in units of 1,000 barrels (42,000 U.S. gallons).
1396878_11_ITEM1_P100_S1	The ICE Futures also offers a WTI Crude Oil Futures contract which trades in units of 1,000 barrels.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P100_S2	The WTI Crude Oil Futures contract is cash settled against the prevailing market price for U.S. light sweet crude oil.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P101_S0	Demand for petroleum products by consumers, as well as agricultural, manufacturing and transportation industries, determines demand for crude oil by refiners.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P101_S1	Since the precursors of product demand are linked to economic activity, crude oil demand will tend to reflect economic conditions.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P101_S2	However, other factors such as weather also influence product and crude oil demand.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P102_S0	Crude oil supply is determined by both economic and political factors.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P102_S1	Oil prices (along with drilling costs, availability of attractive prospects for drilling, taxes and technology, among other factors) determine exploration and development spending, which influence output capacity with a lag.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P102_S2	In the short run, production decisions by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries ( OPEC ) also affect supply and prices.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P102_S3	Oil export embargoes and the current conflict in Iraq represent other routes through which political developments move the market.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P102_S4	It is not possible to predict the aggregate effect of all or any combination of these factors.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P103_S0	Heating oil, also known as No. 2 fuel oil, accounts for approximately 25% of the yield of a barrel of crude oil, the second largest cut from oil after gasoline.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P103_S1	The heating oil futures contract listed and traded on the NYMEX trades in units of 42,000 gallons (1,000 barrels) and is based on delivery in the New York harbor, the principal cash market trading center.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P104_S0	The price of heating oil has historically been volatile.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P105_S0	Natural gas accounts for almost a quarter of U.S. energy consumption.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P106_S0	The natural gas futures contract listed and traded on the NYMEX trades in units of 10,000 mmBtu and is based on delivery at the Henry Hub in Louisiana, the nexus of 16 intra- and interstate natural gas pipeline systems that draw supplies from the region s prolific gas deposits.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P106_S1	The pipelines serve markets throughout the U.S. East Coast, the Gulf Coast, the Midwest, and up to the Canadian border.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P107_S0	The price of natural gas has historically been volatile.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P108_S0	UGA s investment objective is for the changes in percentage terms of its units NAV to reflect the changes in percentage terms of the Benchmark Futures Contract, less UGA s expenses.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P109_S0	UGA invests primarily in Futures Contracts.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P109_S1	UGA seeks to have its aggregate NAV approximate at all times the aggregate market value of the Futures Contracts (or Other Gasoline-Related Investments) it holds.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P110_S0	Other than investing in Futures Contracts and Other Gasoline-Related Investments, UGA only invests in assets to support these investments in Gasoline Interests.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P110_S1	At any given time, most of UGA s investments are in Treasuries, cash and/or cash equivalents that serve as segregated assets supporting UGA s positions in Futures Contracts and Other Gasoline-Related Investments.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P110_S2	For example, the purchase of a Futures Contract with a stated value of $10 million would not require UGA to pay $10 million upon entering into the contract; rather, only a margin deposit, generally of 10% to 15% of the stated value of the Futures Contract, would be required.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P110_S3	To secure its Futures Contract obligations, UGA would deposit the required margin with the futures commission merchant and would separately hold, through its Custodian, Treasuries, cash and/or cash equivalents in an amount equal to the balance of the current market value of the contract, which at the contract s inception would be $10 million minus the amount of the margin deposit, or $9 million (assuming a 10% margin).
1396878_11_ITEM1_P111_S0	As a result of the foregoing, typically 10% to 15% of UGA s assets are held as margin in segregated accounts with a futures commission merchant.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P111_S1	In addition to the Treasuries or cash it posts with the futures commission merchant for the Futures Contracts it owns, UGA holds, through the Custodian, Treasuries, cash and/or cash equivalents that can be posted as margin or as collateral to support its over-the-counter contracts.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P112_S0	UGA earns income from the Treasuries and/or cash equivalents that it purchases, and on the cash it holds through the Custodian.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P112_S1	UGA anticipates that the earned income will increase the NAV and limited partners capital contribution accounts.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P112_S2	UGA reinvests the earned income, holds it in cash, or uses it to pay its expenses.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P112_S3	If UGA reinvests the earned income, it makes investments that are consistent with its investment objective.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P113_S0	UGA invests only in Futures Contracts and Other Gasoline-Related Investments that are traded in sufficient volume to permit, in the opinion of USCF, ease of taking and liquidating positions in these financial interests.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P114_S0	While certain of the gasoline futures contracts traded on the NYMEX can be physically settled, UGA does not intend to take or make physical delivery.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P114_S1	UGA may from time to time trade in Other Gasoline-Related Investments, including contracts based on the spot price of gasoline.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P115_S0	While UGA s historical ratio of initial margin to total assets has generally ranged from approximately 10% to 15%, USCF endeavors to have the value of UGA s Treasuries, cash and/or cash equivalents, whether held by UGA or posted as margin or collateral, at all times approximate the aggregate market value of its obligations under UGA s Futures Contracts and Other Gasoline-Related Investments.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P115_S1	While USCF does not intend to leverage UGA s assets, it is not prohibited from doing so under the LP Agreement.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P116_S0	Borrowings are not used by UGA unless UGA is required to borrow money in the event of physical delivery, UGA trades in cash commodities, or for short-term needs created by unexpected redemptions.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P117_S0	UGA maintains the value of its Treasuries, cash and/or cash equivalents, whether held by UGA or posted as margin or collateral, to at all times approximate the aggregate market value of its obligations under its Futures Contracts and Other Gasoline-Related Investments.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P118_S0	UGA has not established and does not plan to establish credit lines.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P119_S0	In addition to Futures Contracts, there are also a number of listed options on the Futures Contracts on the principal futures exchanges.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P119_S1	These contracts offer investors and hedgers another set of financial vehicles to use in managing exposure to the gasoline market.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P119_S2	Consequently, UGA may purchase options on gasoline futures contracts on these exchanges in pursuing its investment objective.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P120_S0	In addition to the Futures Contracts and options on the Futures Contracts, there also exists an active non-exchange-traded market in derivatives tied to gasoline.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P120_S1	These derivatives transactions (also known as over-the-counter contracts) are usually entered into between two parties.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P120_S2	Unlike most of the exchange-traded Futures Contracts or exchange-traded options on the Futures Contracts, each party to such contract bears the credit risk that the other party may not be able to perform its obligations under its contract.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P121_S0	Some gasoline-based derivatives transactions contain fairly generic terms and conditions and are available from a wide range of participants.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P121_S1	Other gasoline-based derivatives have highly customized terms and conditions and are not as widely available.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P121_S2	Many of these over-the-counter contracts are cash-settled forwards for the future delivery of gasoline- or petroleum-based fuels that have terms similar to the Futures Contracts.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P121_S3	Others take the form of swaps in which the two parties exchange cash flows based on pre-determined formulas tied to the gasoline spot price, forward gasoline price, the Benchmark Futures Contract price, or other gasoline futures contract price.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P121_S4	For example, UGA may enter into over-the-counter derivative contracts whose value will be tied to changes in the difference between the gasoline spot price, the Benchmark Futures Contract price, or some other futures contract price traded on the NYMEX or ICE Futures and the price of other Futures Contracts that may be invested in by UGA.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P122_S0	To protect itself from the credit risk that arises in connection with such contracts, UGA may enter into agreements with each counterparty that provide for the netting of its overall exposure to its counterparty, such as the agreements published by the International Swaps and Derivatives Association, Inc.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P122_S1	UGA also may require that the counterparty be highly rated and/or provide collateral or other credit support to address UGA s exposure to the counterparty.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P123_S0	USCF assesses or reviews, as appropriate, the creditworthiness of each potential or existing counterparty to an over-the-counter contract pursuant to guidelines approved by USCF s Board.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P123_S1	Furthermore, USCF, on behalf of UGA, only enters into over-the-counter contracts with counterparties who are, or are affiliates of, (a) banks regulated by a United States federal bank regulator, (b) broker-dealers regulated by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (the SEC ), (c) insurance companies domiciled in the United States, or (d) producers, users or traders of energy, whether or not regulated by the CFTC.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P123_S2	Any entity acting as a counterparty shall be regulated in either the United States or the United Kingdom unless otherwise approved by USCF s Board after consultation with its legal counsel.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P123_S3	Existing counterparties are also reviewed periodically by USCF.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P124_S0	UGA may employ spreads or straddles in its trading to mitigate the differences in its investment portfolio and its goal of tracking the price of the Benchmark Futures Contract.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P124_S1	UGA would use a spread when it chooses to take simultaneous long and short positions in futures written on the same underlying asset, but with different delivery months.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P124_S2	The effect of holding such combined positions is to adjust the sensitivity of UGA to changes in the price relationship between futures contracts which will expire sooner and those that will expire later.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P124_S3	UGA would use such a spread if USCF felt that taking such long and short positions, when combined with the rest of its holdings, would more closely track the investment goals of UGA, or if USCF felt it would lead to an overall lower cost of trading to achieve a given level of economic exposure to movements in gasoline prices.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P125_S0	UGA would enter into a straddle when it chooses to take an option position consisting of a long (or short) position in both a call option and put option.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P126_S0	The economic effect of holding certain combinations of put options and call options can be very similar to that of owning the underlying futures contracts.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P126_S1	UGA would make use of such a straddle approach if, in the opinion of USCF, the resulting combination would more closely track the investment goals of UGA or if it would lead to an overall lower cost of trading to achieve a given level of economic exposure to movements in gasoline prices.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P127_S0	UGA has not employed any hedging methods since all of its investments have been made over an exchange.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P127_S1	Therefore, UGA has not been exposed to counterparty risk.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P128_S0	UGA has not and will not employ the technique, commonly known as pyramiding, in which the speculator uses unrealized profits on existing positions as variation margin for the purchase or sale of additional positions in the same or another commodity interest.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P129_S0	BBH Co. is the registrar and transfer agent for the units.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P129_S1	BBH Co. is also the Custodian for UGA.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P129_S2	In this capacity, BBH Co. holds UGA s Treasuries, cash and/or cash equivalents pursuant to a custodial agreement.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P129_S3	In addition, in its capacity as Administrator for UGA, BBH Co. performs certain administrative and accounting services for UGA and prepares certain SEC and CFTC reports on behalf of UGA.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P129_S4	USCF pays BBH Co. s fees for these services.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P130_S0	BBH Co. s principal business address is 50 Milk Street, Boston, MA 02109-3661.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P131_S0	BBH Co., a private bank founded in 1818, is not a publicly held company nor is it insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P131_S1	BBH Co. is authorized to conduct a commercial banking business in accordance with the provisions of Article IV of the New York State Banking Law, New York Banking Law 160 181, and is subject to regulation, supervision, and examination by the New York State Banking Department.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P131_S2	BBH Co. is also licensed to conduct a commercial banking business by the Commonwealths of Massachusetts and Pennsylvania and is subject to supervision and examination by the banking supervisors of those states.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P132_S0	UGA also employs ALPS Distributors, Inc. as a Marketing Agent.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P132_S1	USCF pays the Marketing Agent an annual fee.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P132_S2	In no event may the aggregate compensation paid to the Marketing Agent and any affiliate of USCF for distribution-related services in connection with the offering of units exceed ten percent (10%) of the gross proceeds of the offering.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P133_S0	ALPS s principal business address is 1290 Broadway, Suite 1100, Denver, CO 80203.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P134_S0	ALPS is the marketing agent for UGA.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P135_S0	ALPS is a broker-dealer registered with the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority ( FINRA ) and a member of the Securities Investor Protection Corporation.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P136_S0	UBS Securities LLC ( UBS Securities ) is UGA s futures commission merchant.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P136_S1	UGA and UBS Securities have entered into an Institutional Futures Client Account Agreement.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P136_S2	This Agreement requires UBS Securities to provide services to UGA in connection with the purchase and sale of Gasoline Interests that may be purchased or sold by or through UBS Securities for UGA s account.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P136_S3	UGA pays the fees of UBS Securities.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P137_S0	UBS Securities principal business address is 677 Washington Blvd, Stamford, CT 06901.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P138_S0	UBS Securities is a futures clearing broker for UGA .
1396878_11_ITEM1_P138_S1	UBS Securities is registered in the United States with FINRA as a broker- dealer and with the CFTC as a futures commission merchant.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P139_S0	UBS Securities is a member of various U.S. futures and securities exchanges.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P140_S0	Like most securities firms, UBS is and has been a defendant in numerous legal proceedings, including actions brought by regulatory organizations and government agencies, relating to its securities and commodities business that allege various violations of federal and state securities laws.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P140_S1	UBS AG, the ultimate parent company to UBS Securities, files annual reports and quarterly reports to the SEC in which it discloses material information about UBS matters, including information about any material litigation or regulatory investigations.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P140_S2	Actions with respect to UBS Securities futures commission merchant business are publicly available on the website of the National Futures Association (http://www.nfa.futures.org/).
1396878_11_ITEM1_P141_S0	On June 27, 2007, the Securities Division of the Secretary of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts ( Massachusetts Securities Division ) filed an administrative complaint (the Complaint ) and notice of adjudicatory proceeding against UBS Securities, captioned In The Matter of UBS Securities, LLC, Docket No. E-2007-0049, which alleged that UBS Securities violated the Massachusetts Uniform Securities Act (the Act ) and related regulations by providing the advisers for certain hedge funds with gifts and gratuities in the form of below market office rents, personal loans with below market interest rates, event tickets, and other perks, in order to induce those hedge fund advisers to increase or retain their level of prime brokerage fees paid to UBS Securities.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P141_S1	The Complaint seeks a cease and desist order from conduct that violates the Act and regulations, to censure UBS Securities, to require UBS Securities to pay an administrative fine of an unspecified amount, and to find as fact the allegations of the Complaint.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P142_S0	In the summer of 2008, the Massachusetts Securities Division, Texas State Securities Board, and the New York Attorney General (the NYAG ) all brought actions against UBS Securities and UBS Financial Services, Inc. ( UBS Financial ), alleging violations of various state law anti-fraud provisions in connection with the marketing and sale of auction rate securities.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P143_S0	On August 8, 2008, UBS Securities and UBS Financial reached agreements in principle with the SEC, the NYAG, the Massachusetts Securities Division and other state regulatory agencies represented by the North American Securities Administrators Association ( NASAA ) to restore liquidity to all remaining client s holdings of auction rate securities by June 30, 2012.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P143_S1	On October 2, 2008, UBS Securities and UBS Financial entered into a final consent agreement with the Massachusetts Securities Division settling all allegations in the Massachusetts Securities Division s administrative proceeding against UBS Securities and UBS Financial with regards to the auction rate securities matter.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P143_S2	On December 11, 2008, UBS Securities and UBS Financial executed an Assurance of Discontinuance in the auction rate securities settlement with the NYAG.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P144_S0	On the same day, UBS Securities and UBS Financial finalized settlements with the SEC.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P144_S1	UBS paid penalties of $75M to NYAG and an additional $75M to be apportioned among the participating NASAA states.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P144_S2	In March 2010, UBS and NASAA agreed on final settlement terms, pursuant to which, UBS agreed to provide client liquidity up to an additional $200 million.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P145_S0	On August 14, 2008 the New Hampshire Bureau of Securities Regulation filed an administrative action against UBS Securities relating to a student loan issuer, the New Hampshire Higher Education Loan Corp. ( NHHELCO ).
1396878_11_ITEM1_P145_S1	The complaint alleges fraudulent and unethical conduct in violation of New Hampshire state statues.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P145_S2	On April 14, 2010, UBS entered into a Consent Order resolving all of the Bureau s claims.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P145_S3	UBS paid $750,000 to the Bureau for all costs associated with the Bureau s investigation.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P145_S4	UBS entered a separate civil settlement with NHHELCO and provided a total financial benefit of $20M to NHHELCO.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P146_S0	On April 29, 2010, the CFTC issued an order with respect to UBS Securities and levied a fine of $200,000.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P146_S1	The Order stated that on February 6, 2009, UBS Securities employee broker aided and abetted UBS Securities customer s concealment of material facts from the NYMEX in violation of Section 9(a)(4) of the CEA, 7 U.S.C. 13(a)(4) (2006).
1396878_11_ITEM1_P147_S0	Pursuant to NYMEX Rules, a block trade must be reported to the NYMEX within five minutes of the time of execution consistent with the requirements of NYMEX Rule 6.21C(A)(6).
1396878_11_ITEM1_P147_S1	Although the block trade in question was executed earlier in the day, UBS Securities employee broker aided and abetted its customer s concealment of facts when, in response to the customer s request to delay reporting the trade until after the close of trading, UBS Securities employee did not report the trade until after the close.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P147_S2	Because the employee broker undertook his actions within the scope of his employment, pursuant to Section 2(a)(1)(B) of the CEA, 7 U.S.C. 2(a)(1)(B) (2006), and SEC Regulation 1.2, 17 C.F.R. 1.2 (2009), UBS Securities is liable for the employee broker s aiding and abetting of its customer s violation of Section 9(a)(4) of the CEA.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P147_S3	The fine has been paid and the matter is now closed.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P148_S0	UBS Securities will act only as clearing broker for UGA and as such will be paid commissions for executing and clearing trades on behalf of UGA.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P148_S1	UBS Securities has not passed upon the adequacy or accuracy of this annual report on Form 10-K. UBS Securities neither will act in any supervisory capacity with respect to USCF nor participate in the management of USCF or UGA.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P149_S0	UBS Securities is not affiliated with UGA or USCF.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P149_S1	Therefore, UGA does not believe that UGA has any conflicts of interest with UBS Securities or their trading principals arising from their acting as UGA s futures commission merchant.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P150_S0	Currently, USCF does not employ commodity trading advisors for trading of UGA contracts.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P150_S1	USCF currently does, however, employ a trading advisor for USCI SummerHaven Investment Management, LLC ( SummerHaven ).
1396878_11_ITEM1_P150_S2	If, in the future, USCF does employ commodity trading advisors for UGA, it will choose each advisor based on arm s-length negotiations and will consider the advisor s experience, fees and reputation.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P151_S0	Minimum amount of $75,000 annually for its custody, fund accounting and fund administration services rendered to all funds, as well as a $20,000 annual fee for its transfer agency services.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P151_S1	In addition, an asset-based charge of (a) 0.06% for the first $500 million of UGA s and the Related Public Funds combined net assets, (b) 0.0465% for UGA s and the Related Public Funds combined net assets greater than $500 million but less than $1 billion, and (c) 0.035% once UGA s and the Related Public Funds combined net assets exceed $1 billion.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P152_S0	0.06% on UGA s assets up to $3 billion and 0.04% on UGA s assets in excess of $3 billion.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P153_S0	The annual minimum amount will not apply if the asset-based charge for all accounts in the aggregate exceeds $75,000.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P153_S1	USCF also will pay transaction charge fees to BBH Co., ranging from $7.00 to $15.00 per transaction for the funds.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P154_S0	Fees are calculated on a daily basis (accrued at 1/365 of the applicable percentage of NAV on that day) and paid on a monthly basis.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P155_S0	NAV is calculated by taking the current market value of UGA s total assets and subtracting any liabilities.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P156_S0	Fees are calculated on a daily basis (accrued at 1/365 of the applicable percentage of NAV on that day) and paid on a monthly basis.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P157_S0	UGA is responsible for its pro rata share of the assets held by UGA and the Related Public Funds, other than USBO and USCI.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P158_S0	Expenses Paid by UGA through December 31, 2010 in dollar terms:
1396878_11_ITEM1_P159_S0	Includes expenses relating to the registration of additional units, legal fees, auditing fees, printing expenses, licensing fees, tax reporting fees, prepaid insurance expenses and miscellaneous expenses and fees and expenses paid to the independent directors of USCF.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P160_S0	USCF, though under no obligation to do so, agreed to pay certain expenses, to the extent that such expenses exceeded 0.15% (15 basis points) of UGA s NAV, on an annualized basis, through at least June 30, 2011.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P160_S1	USCF has no obligation to pay such expenses in subsequent periods.
1396878_11_ITEM1_P161_S0	Expenses Paid by UGA through December 31, 2010 as a Percentage of Average Daily Net Assets:
