1396878_14_ITEM15_P6_S0	Ethics are important to United States Commodity Funds LLC (the Company or USCF ) and to each member of our management, our investment professionals, and our employees.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P6_S1	The Company is committed to the highest ethical standards and to conducting business with the highest level of integrity.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P6_S2	The following sets forth the Ninth Amended Code of Conduct and Ethics policy of the Company, adopted on March 1, 2006, last amended on February 20, 2014.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P7_S0	All officers, directors and employees of the Company are responsible for maintaining this level of integrity and for complying with the policies contained in this Code.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P7_S1	If you have a question or concern about what is proper conduct for you or anyone else, please raise these concerns with any member of management, or follow the procedures outlined this Code.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P8_S0	reaffirm and promote our commitment to a corporate culture that values honesty and accountability.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P9_S0	All employees, as a condition of employment or continued employment, will acknowledge in writing that they have received a copy of this Code, read it, and understand that the Code contains our expectations regarding their conduct.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P10_S0	Finally, you should know that this Code is designed to satisfy the standards contained in the Federal Sentencing Guidelines for Organizations published by the U.S. Department of Justice.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P10_S1	U.S. federal courts are bound to apply the Federal Sentencing Guidelines for Organizations when sentencing companies convicted of federal offenses arising from the illegal acts of one or more employees.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P10_S2	The Federal Sentencing Guidelines for Organizations provide for substantial leniency in sentencing of a company from otherwise severe mandatory penalties, where the company had in effect an adequate compliance program at the time of the illegal activity.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P11_S0	You must avoid any conflict, or the appearance of a conflict, between your personal interests and our interests.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P11_S1	A conflict exists when your personal interest in any way interferes with our interests, or when you take any action or have any interest that may make it difficult for you to perform your job objectively and effectively.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P11_S2	For example, a conflict of interest probably exists if:
1396878_14_ITEM15_P12_S0	you use or communicate confidential information obtained in the course of your work for your or another s personal benefit.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P13_S0	Each of us has a duty to advance the legitimate interests of the Company when the opportunity to do so presents itself.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P14_S0	compete, or prepare to compete, with us.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P15_S0	We are committed to a policy of full, fair, accurate, timely, and understandable disclosure to shareholders of all material information regarding our business.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P15_S1	This policy extends to our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission ( SEC ) and to all other public communications.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P15_S2	All individuals involved in our SEC reporting process and in preparing and making public communications regarding our business must take all reasonable steps to comply with this policy.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P16_S0	You must not disclose confidential information regarding the Company, our service providers, the Index Funds Trust, the Funds or our affiliates, unless disclosure is authorized or required by law.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P16_S1	Confidential information includes all non-public information that might be harmful to, or useful to the competitors of, the Company, the Index Funds Trust, any Fund, our affiliates, our service providers, or our other business partners.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P17_S0	You must endeavor to deal fairly with companies or individuals with whom we do business or come into contact, including fellow employees of the Company and our competitors.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P17_S1	You must not take unfair advantage of these or other parties by means of:
1396878_14_ITEM15_P18_S0	Our assets are to be used only for legitimate business purposes.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P18_S1	You should protect our assets and ensure that they are used efficiently.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P19_S0	Incidental personal use of telephones, fax machines, copy machines, personal computers and similar equipment is generally allowed if there is no significant added cost to us, it does not interfere with your work duties, and is not related to an illegal activity or to any outside business.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P20_S0	Each of us has a duty to comply with all laws, rules and regulations that apply to our business.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P20_S1	Highlighted below are some of the key compliance guidelines that must be followed.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P21_S0	It is against the law to buy or sell securities using material information that is not available to the public.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P21_S1	Individuals who give this inside information to others may be liable to the same extent as the individuals who trade while in possession of such information.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P21_S2	You must not trade the shares of any Fund, or the securities of our affiliates, our service providers, or any of our other business partners while in the possession of inside information.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P22_S0	It is against the law to discharge, demote, suspend, threaten, harass, or discriminate in any manner against an employee who provides information or otherwise assists in investigations or proceedings relating to violations of federal securities laws or other federal laws prohibiting fraud against shareholders.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P22_S1	You must not discriminate in any way against an employee who engages in these whistleblower activities.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P23_S0	You must adhere to appropriate procedures governing the retention and destruction of records consistent with applicable laws, regulations and our policies.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P23_S1	You may not destroy, alter or falsify any document that may be relevant to a threatened or pending lawsuit or governmental investigation.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P24_S0	Please talk to any member of management if you have any questions about how to comply with the above regulations and other laws, rules and regulations.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P25_S0	We are committed to providing equal opportunity in all of our employment practices including selection, hiring, promotion, transfer, and compensation of all qualified applicants and employees without regard to race, color, sex or gender, religion, age, national origin, handicap, disability, citizenship status, or any other status protected by law.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P25_S1	With this in mind, there are certain behaviors that will not be tolerated.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P25_S2	These include harassment, violence, intimidation, and discrimination of any kind involving race, color, religion, gender, age, national origin, disability, or marital status.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P26_S0	We require honest and accurate recording and reporting of information in order to make responsible business decisions.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P26_S1	This includes such data as quality, safety, and personnel records, as well as financial records.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P27_S0	All financial books, records and accounts must accurately reflect transactions and events, and conform both to required accounting principles and to our system of internal controls.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P27_S1	No false or artificial entries may be made.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P28_S0	The law requires us to maintain certain types of corporate records, usually for specified periods of time.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P28_S1	Failure to retain those records for those minimum periods could subject us to penalties and fines, cause the loss of rights, obstruct justice, place us in contempt of court, or seriously disadvantage us in litigation.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P29_S0	From time to time we establish retention or destruction policies in order to ensure legal compliance.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P29_S1	We expect you to fully comply with any published records retention or destruction policies, provided that you should note the following exception: If you believe, or we inform you, that our records are relevant to any litigation or governmental action, or any potential litigation or action, then you must preserve those records until we determine the records are no longer needed.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P29_S2	This exception supersedes any previously or subsequently established destruction policies for those records.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P29_S3	If you believe that this exception may apply, or have any questions regarding the possible applicability of that exception, please contact our Chief Compliance Officer (the Chief Compliance Officer ).
1396878_14_ITEM15_P30_S0	No funds of the Company or of any Funds may be given directly to political candidates.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P30_S1	You may, however, engage in political activity with your own resources on your own time.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P31_S0	We must speak with a unified voice in all dealings with the press and other media.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P31_S1	As a result, the President and CEO is the sole contact for media seeking information about the Company, the Index Funds Trust or any Fund.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P31_S2	Any requests from the media must be referred to him.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P31_S3	Unless another individual(s) is so authorized by the President and CEO.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P31_S4	In the event the President and CEO and other authorized individual(s) are not available, clearance must be obtained through the Chief Compliance Officer.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P32_S0	USCF, the Funds and the Index Funds Trust produce limited promotional material, which includes websites and a fact-sheet for each of the Funds.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P32_S1	All promotional material developed by USCF, the Funds, including material posted on a website or printed on a fact-sheet, is reviewed for accuracy and approved prior to its public release by USCF s counsel to ensure its compliance with the relevant requirements of the SEC, the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority ( FINRA ), the National Futures Association ( NFA ) and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission ( CFTC ), and any other applicable regulatory authority.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P33_S0	In addition to procedures intended to safeguard against a Fund fact-sheet being misleading or deceptive, it is a USCF policy that Fund fact-sheets may only be distributed to the public when accompanied by the current applicable Fund prospectus.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P34_S0	As noted above, all content to be included on a Fund website is reviewed and approved by USCF s counsel prior to publication of such content on such website.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P34_S1	A review of website information is performed each time new information placed on the website would lead to a substantively new version of the web page.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P34_S2	The review and approval of website material is documented by the supervisor in charge of such review.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P35_S0	USCF does not allow the use of personal websites by its employees or agents for the solicitation of business to any of the Funds.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P36_S0	USCF, or its service providers, maintains the supporting documentation for all statements, claims and performance results referenced in promotional material prepared by or on behalf of the Funds.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P37_S0	Information generated in our business is a valuable asset.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P37_S1	Protecting this information plays an important role in our growth and ability to compete.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P37_S2	Such information includes business and research plans; objectives and strategies; trade secrets; unpublished financial information; salary and benefits data; and business partner lists.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P37_S3	Employees who have access to our intellectual property information are obligated to safeguard it from unauthorized access and must:
1396878_14_ITEM15_P38_S0	Not share this information with other employees except on a legitimate need to know basis.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P39_S0	We may provide an e-mail system and Internet access to certain of our employees to help them do their work.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P39_S1	You may use the e-mail system and the Internet only for legitimate business purposes in the course of your duties.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P39_S2	Incidental and occasional personal use is permitted, but never for personal gain or any improper use.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P39_S3	Further, you are prohibited from discussing or posting information regarding the Company, the Index Funds Trust or any of the Funds in any external electronic forum, including Internet chat rooms or electronic bulletin boards.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P40_S0	All employees engaged in the transmission of futures-related e-mails will be monitored periodically to ensure the accuracy of the information contained in such emails.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P40_S1	Review of such emails is performed by ALPS, as principal to registered representatives on an annual basis.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P40_S2	Review may also be undertaken by the Chief Compliance Officer and Counsel.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P40_S3	This type of review is performed in conformity with NFA and FINRA guidance on e-mail review, in consideration of the fact that USCF generally communicates with institutional or relatively sophisticated clients, while USCF s marketing agent handles most communication with the general public.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P41_S0	You are responsible for compliance with the rules, standards and principles described in this Code.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P41_S1	In addition, you should be alert to possible violations of the Code by the Company s employees, officers and directors, and you are expected to report a violation promptly.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P41_S2	Normally, reports should be made to one s immediate supervisor.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P41_S3	Under some circumstances, it may be impractical or you may feel uncomfortable raising a matter with your supervisor.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P41_S4	In those instances, you are encouraged to contact our Chief Compliance Officer or General Counsel who will investigate and report the matter to the Board of Directors, as the circumstance dictates.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P41_S5	You will also be expected to cooperate in an investigation of a violation.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P42_S0	Anyone who has a concern about our conduct, the conduct of an officer of the Company or our accounting, internal accounting controls or auditing matters, may communicate that concern to the Chief Compliance Officer or to the Audit Committee of the Board of Directors by direct communication with our Chairman of the Audit Committee or by e-mail or in writing.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P42_S1	In addition, anyone who has a concern specifically about the Funds, may communicate that concern to the Chief Compliance Officer or to the Audit Committee.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P42_S2	All reported concerns shall be forwarded to the Chief Compliance Officer or the Audit Committee, as applicable, in the same way that other concerns are addressed by us.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P42_S3	The status of all outstanding concerns forwarded to the Audit Committee or the Chief Compliance Officer will be reported on a quarterly basis by our Chairman of the Audit Committee or Chief Compliance Officer, as applicable.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P42_S4	The Audit Committee or Chief Compliance Officer, as applicable, may direct that certain matters be presented to the full Board of Directors and may also direct special treatment, including the retention of outside advisors or counsel, for any concern reported to it.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P43_S0	All reports will be investigated and whenever possible, requests for confidentiality shall be honored.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P43_S1	And, while anonymous reports will be accepted, please understand that anonymity may hinder or impede the investigation of a report.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P43_S2	All cases of questionable activity or improper actions will be reviewed for appropriate action, discipline or corrective actions.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P43_S3	Whenever possible, we will keep confidential the identity of employees, officers or directors who are accused of violations , unless or until it has been determined that a violation has occurred.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P44_S0	There will be no reprisal, retaliation or adverse action taken against any employee who, in good faith, reports or assists in the investigation of, a violation or suspected violation, or who makes an inquiry about the appropriateness of an anticipated or actual course of action.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P45_S0	For reporting concerns about the conduct of the Company, or any Fund, the conduct of an officer of the Company, or about accounting, internal accounting controls or auditing matters of the Company, or any Fund, you may use the following means of communication:
1396878_14_ITEM15_P46_S0	If to the Chief Compliance Officer:
1396878_14_ITEM15_P47_S0	If to the Chairman of the Audit Committee:
1396878_14_ITEM15_P48_S0	Complaints from shareholders of a Fund may raise compliance issues that need to be addressed in an expeditious manner.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P48_S1	All complaints received by any associated person of USCF or any Fund are to be forwarded to the Chief Compliance Officer.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P48_S2	Associated persons have been instructed to forward to the Chief Compliance Officer any oral questions that cannot be readily addressed so that such questions can be treated as complaints if the Chief Compliance Officer deems necessary.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P48_S3	It is the general policy of USCF, and the Funds to answer all complaints.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P48_S4	A discussion of any complaints received will be an agenda item at each quarterly meeting of the Board of Directors of USCF.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P49_S0	The Chief Compliance Officer s duties with respect to shareholder complaints include: (1) maintaining a log that documents all complaints, (2) investigating complaints as needed, (3) making a recommendation for resolution of all complaints received, and (4) instituting any necessary changes to policies and procedures in connection with or in response to complaints.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P50_S0	USCF maintains records of all written complaints that are received by any party in connection with the Funds, as well as records relating to the resolution of such complaints.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P51_S0	In light of the responsibilities placed on USCF s marketing agent, it is likely that the marketing agent will also receive complaints from shareholders from time to time.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P51_S1	The marketing agent will address these complaints pursuant to its own procedures, but notice of such complaints will be forwarded to the Chief Compliance Officer to be documented in the complaint log.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P52_S0	The marketing agent will be responsible for addressing any complaints that it receives pursuant to the marketing agent s own procedures and will forward notice of material complaints to the Chief Compliance Officer.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P52_S1	The Chief Compliance Officer must follow the complaint handling procedures described below:
1396878_14_ITEM15_P53_S0	All violations of the Code will result in appropriate corrective action, up to and including dismissal.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P53_S1	If the violation involves potentially criminal activity, the individual or individuals in question will be reported, as warranted, to the appropriate authorities.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P54_S0	All of the officers, directors, and employees are subject to this Code.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P54_S1	Any waiver of this Code for an executive officer or director of the Company may only be made by the Board of Directors or the Audit Committee.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P54_S2	Any waiver of the Code for an officer or member of our Boards of Directors must be promptly disclosed to shareholders.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P55_S0	The Chief Compliance Officer of USCF is responsible for overseeing our ethics training program.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P55_S1	The Chief Compliance Officer of USCF conducts an annual review of USCF s ethics training policy and will require ethics training on an as needed basis.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P56_S0	This acknowledgment is to be signed and returned to our Chief Compliance Officer, Carolyn M .Yu, and will be retained as part of your permanent personnel file.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P57_S0	LLC s Code of Business Conduct and Ethics, read it, and understand that the Code contains the expectations of United States Commodity Funds LLC regarding employee conduct.
1396878_14_ITEM15_P57_S1	I also understand that the Code is issued for informational purposes and that it is not intended to create, nor does it represent, a contract of employment.

1396878_14_ITEM15_P62_S0	The registrant s other certifying officer(s) and I have disclosed, based on our most recent evaluation of internal control over financial reporting, to the registrant s auditors and the audit committee of the registrant s Board of Directors (or persons performing the equivalent functions):
1396878_14_ITEM15_P63_S0	(b) Any fraud, whether or not material, that involves management or other employees who have a significant role in the registrant s internal control over financial reporting.

1396878_14_ITEM15_P65_S0	The registrant s other certifying officer(s) and I have disclosed, based on our most recent evaluation of internal control over financial reporting, to the registrant s auditors and the audit committee of the registrant s Board of Directors (or persons performing the equivalent functions):
1396878_14_ITEM15_P66_S0	(b) Any fraud, whether or not material, that involves management or other employees who have a significant role in the registrant s internal control over financial reporting.

1396878_14_ITEM15_P69_S0	In connection with the Annual Report on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2013 (the Report ) of United States Gasoline Fund, LP (the Registrant ), as filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on the date hereof, I, Howard Mah, the Chief Financial Officer of United States Commodity Funds LLC, General Partner of the Registrant, hereby certify, to the best of my knowledge, that:
1396878_14_ITEM15_P70_S0	(2) The information contained in the Report fairly presents, in all material respects, the financial condition and results of operations of the Registrant.
1396878_14_ITEM5_P0_S0	Market for Registrant s Common Equity, Related Stockholder Matters and Issuer Purchases of Equity Securities.
1396878_14_ITEM5_P1_S0	UGA s shares have traded on the NYSE Arca under the symbol UGA since November 25, 2008.
1396878_14_ITEM5_P1_S1	Prior to trading on the NYSE Arca, UGA s shares traded on the AMEX under the symbol UGA since its initial public offering on February 26, 2008.
1396878_14_ITEM5_P1_S2	The following table sets forth the range of reported high and low sales prices of the shares as reported on the AMEX and NYSE Arca, as applicable, for the periods indicated below.
1396878_14_ITEM5_P2_S0	As of December 31, 2013, UGA had approximately 4,692 holders of shares.
1396878_14_ITEM5_P3_S0	UGA has not made and does not currently intend to make cash distributions to its shareholders.
1396878_14_ITEM5_P4_S0	UGA does not purchase shares directly from its shareholders; however, in connection with its redemption of baskets held by Authorized Purchasers, UGA redeemed 10 baskets (comprising 500,000 shares) during the year ended December 31, 2013.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P0_S0	Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P1_S0	The following discussion should be read in conjunction with the financial statements and the notes thereto of UGA included elsewhere in this annual report on Form 10-K.

1396878_14_ITEM7_P2_S3	These forward-looking statements are based on assumptions that may be incorrect, and UGA cannot assure investors that the projections included in these forward-looking statements will come to pass.

1396878_14_ITEM7_P3_S0	UGA has based the forward-looking statements included in this annual report on Form 10-K on information available to it on the date of this annual report on Form 10-K, and UGA assumes no obligation to update any such forward-looking statements.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P3_S1	Although UGA undertakes no obligation to revise or update any forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise, investors are advised to consult any additional disclosures that UGA may make directly to them or through reports that UGA in the future files with the SEC, including annual reports on Form 10-K, quarterly reports on Form 10-Q and current reports on Form 8-K.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P4_S0	UGA, a Delaware limited partnership, is a commodity pool that issues shares that may be purchased and sold on the NYSE Arca.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P4_S1	The investment objective of UGA is for the daily changes in percentage terms of its shares per share NAV to reflect the daily changes in percentage terms of the spot price of gasoline, as measured by the daily changes in the price of the futures contract for unleaded gasoline (also known as reformulated gasoline blendstock for oxygen blending, or RBOB , for delivery to the New York harbor), traded on the NYMEX that is the near month contract to expire, except when the near month contract is within two weeks of expiration, in which case it will be measured by the futures contract that is the next month contract to expire (the Benchmark Futures Contract ), less UGA s expenses.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P4_S2	Near month contract means the next contract traded on the NYMEX due to expire.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P4_S3	Next month contract means the first contract traded on the NYMEX due to expire after the near month contract.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P5_S0	It is not the intent of UGA to be operated in a fashion such that the per share NAV will equal, in dollar terms, the spot price of gasoline or any particular futures contract based on gasoline.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P5_S1	It is not the intent of UGA to be operated in a fashion such that its per share NAV will reflect the percentage change of the price of any particular futures contract as measured over a time period greater than one day.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P5_S2	USCF believes that it is not practical to manage the portfolio to achieve such an investment goal when investing in Futures Contracts and Other Gasoline-Related Investments.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P6_S0	UGA seeks to achieve its investment objective by investing in a combination of Futures Contracts and Other Gasoline-Related Investments such that daily changes in its per share NAV, measured in percentage terms, will closely track the daily changes in the price of the Benchmark Futures Contract, also measured in percentage terms.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P6_S1	USCF believes the daily changes in the price of the Benchmark Futures Contract have historically exhibited a close correlation with the daily changes in the spot price of gasoline.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P7_S0	On any valuation day, the Benchmark Futures Contract is the near month futures contract for gasoline traded on the NYMEX unless the near month contract is within two weeks of expiration in which case the Benchmark Futures Contract is the next month contract for gasoline traded on the NYMEX.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P8_S0	The regulation of commodity interest trading in the United States and other countries is an evolving area of the law.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P8_S1	The various statements made in this summary are subject to modification by legislative action and changes in the rules and regulations of the CFTC, the NFA, the futures exchanges, clearing organizations and other regulatory bodies.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P8_S2	Pending final resolution of all applicable regulatory requirements, some examples of how new rules and regulations could impact UGA are discussed in Item 1.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P9_S0	Business and Item 1A. Risk Factors in this annual report on Form 10-K.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P10_S0	Gasoline futures prices were volatile during the year ended December 31, 2013.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P10_S1	The price of the Benchmark Futures Contract started the year at $2.7617 per gallon.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P10_S2	Prices hit a peak on February 19, 2013 of $3.3152 per gallon.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P10_S3	The low for the year was on November 7, 2013, when the prices dropped to $2.5031 per gallon.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P10_S4	The year ended with the Benchmark Futures Contract at $2.7859 per gallon, up approximately 0.88% over the year (investors are cautioned that these represent prices for gasoline on a wholesale basis and should not be directly compared to retail prices at a gasoline service station).
1396878_14_ITEM7_P10_S5	UGA s per share NAV began the year at $58.39 and ended the year at $59.89 on December 31, 2013, an increase of approximately 2.57% over the year.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P10_S6	UGA s per share NAV reached its high for the year on February 14, 2013 at $65.48 and reached its low for the year on November 7, 2013 at $53.74.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P11_S0	The Benchmark Futures Contract prices listed above began with the February 2013 contract and ended with the February 2014 contract.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P11_S1	The increase of approximately 0.88% on the Benchmark Futures Contract listed above is a hypothetical return only and could not actually be achieved by an investor holding Futures Contracts.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P11_S2	An investment in Futures Contracts would need to be rolled forward during the time period described in order to achieve such a result.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P11_S3	Furthermore, the change in the nominal price of these differing Futures Contracts, measured from the start of the year to the end of the year, does not represent the actual benchmark results that UGA seeks to track, which are more fully described below in the section titled Tracking UGA s Benchmark.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P12_S0	During the year ended December 31, 2013, the gasoline futures market exhibited periods of both contango and backwardation, with the market in backwardation the majority of the time.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P12_S1	During periods of contango, the price of the near month gasoline Futures Contract was typically lower than the price of the next month gasoline Futures Contract, or contracts further away from expiration.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P12_S2	On days when the market was in backwardation, the price of the near month gasoline Futures Contract was typically higher than the price of the next month gasoline Futures Contract, or contracts further away from expiration.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P12_S3	For a discussion of the impact of backwardation and contango on total returns, see Term Structure of Gasoline Prices and the Impact on Total Returns below.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P13_S0	The per share NAV of UGA s shares is calculated once each NYSE Arca trading day.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P13_S1	The per share NAV for a particular trading day is released after 4:00 p.m. New York time.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P13_S2	Trading during the core trading session on the NYSE Arca typically closes at 4:00 p.m. New York time.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P13_S3	The Administrator uses the NYMEX closing price (determined at the earlier of the close of the NYMEX or 2:30 p.m. New York time) for the contracts held on the NYMEX, but calculates or determines the value of all other UGA investments, including ICE Futures contracts or other futures contracts, as of the earlier of the close of the NYSE Arca or 4:00 p.m. New York time.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P14_S0	On February 26, 2008, UGA listed its shares on the AMEX under the ticker symbol UGA.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P14_S1	On that day, UGA established its initial offering price at $50.00 per share and issued 300,000 shares to the initial Authorized Purchaser, Merrill Lynch Professional Clearing Group, in exchange for $15,001,000 in cash.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P14_S2	As a result of the acquisition of the AMEX by NYSE Euronext, UGA s shares no longer trade on the AMEX and commenced trading on the NYSE Arca on November 25, 2008.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P15_S0	Since its initial offering of 30,000,000 shares, UGA has registered one subsequent offering of its shares: 50,000,000 shares which were registered with the SEC on April 30, 2010.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P15_S1	As of December 31, 2013, UGA had issued 9,100,000 shares, 950,000 of which were outstanding.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P15_S2	As of December 31, 2013, there were 70,900,000 shares registered but not yet issued.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P16_S0	More shares may have been issued by UGA than are outstanding due to the redemption of shares.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P16_S1	Unlike funds that are registered under the 1940 Act, shares that have been redeemed by UGA cannot be resold by UGA.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P16_S2	As a result, UGA contemplates that additional offerings of its shares will be registered with the SEC in the future in anticipation of additional issuances and redemptions.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P17_S0	As of December 31, 2013, UGA had the following Authorized Purchasers: Citadel Securities LLC, Citigroup Global Markets Inc., Credit Suisse Securities USA LLC, Deutsche Bank Securities Inc., JP Morgan Securities Inc., Merrill Lynch Professional Clearing Corp., Morgan Stanley Company Inc., NewEdge USA LLC, Nomura Securities International Inc., RBC Capital Markets Corporation, SG Americas Securities LLC, Virtu Financial BD LLC and Virtu Financial Capital Markets.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P18_S0	As of December 31, 2013, the total unrealized gain on Futures Contracts owned or held on that day was $2,598,553 and UGA established cash deposits and investments in Treasuries and money market funds that were equal to $54,246,641.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P18_S1	UGA held 96.21% of its cash assets in overnight deposits and investments in Treasuries and money market funds at the Custodian, while 3.79% of the cash balance was held as investments in Treasuries and margin deposits for the Futures Contracts purchased at the FCM.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P18_S2	The ending per share NAV on December 31, 2013 was $59.89.

1396878_14_ITEM7_P19_S1	UGA held 91.60% of its cash assets in overnight deposits and investments in money market funds at the Custodian, while 8.40% of the cash balance was held as investments in Treasuries and margin deposits for the Futures Contracts purchased at the FCM.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P19_S2	The decrease in cash assets in overnight deposits and investments in Treasuries and money market funds for December 31, 2013, as compared to December 31, 2012, was the result of UGA s smaller size during the year ended December 31, 2013 as measured by total net assets.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P19_S3	The ending per share NAV on December 31, 2012 was $58.39.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P19_S4	The increase in the per share NAV for December 31, 2013 as compared to December 31, 2012 was primarily due to the decrease in the price of the Benchmark Futures Contracts between the year ended December 31, 2012 and the year ended December 31, 2013.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P20_S0	By comparison, as of December 31, 2011, the total unrealized gain on gasoline Futures Contracts owned or held on that day was $4,729,725 and UGA established cash deposits and investments in Treasuries and money market funds that were equal to $72,599,046.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P20_S1	UGA held 93.85% of its cash assets in overnight deposits and investments in money market funds at the Custodian, while 6.15% of the cash balance was held as investments in Treasuries and margin deposits for the Futures Contracts purchased at the FCM.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P20_S2	The decrease in cash assets in overnight deposits and investments in Treasuries and money market funds for December 31, 2012 as compared to December 31, 2011, was the result of UGA s smaller size during the year ended December 31, 2012 as measured by total net assets.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P20_S3	The ending per share NAV on December 31, 2011 was $48.37.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P20_S4	The increase in the per share NAV for December 31, 2012, as compared to December 31, 2011 was primarily due to the impact of backwardation and the increase in the price of the Benchmark Futures Contract between the year ended December 31, 2011 and the year ended December 31, 2012.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P21_S0	UGA s expenses consist of investment management fees, brokerage fees and commissions, certain offering costs, licensing fees, the fees and expenses of the independent directors of USCF and expenses relating to tax accounting and reporting requirements.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P21_S1	The management fee that UGA pays to USCF is calculated as a percentage of the total net assets of UGA.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P21_S2	UGA pays USCF a management fee of 0.60% of its average net assets.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P21_S3	The fee is accrued daily and paid monthly.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P22_S0	During the year ended December 31, 2013, the average daily total net assets of UGA were $58,529,442.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P22_S1	The management fee incurred by UGA during the year amounted to $351,177.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P22_S2	By comparison, during the year ended December 31, 2012, the average daily total net assets of UGA were $91,674,247.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P22_S3	The management fee paid by UGA during the year amounted to $550,046.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P22_S4	By comparison, during the year ended December 31, 2011, the average daily total net assets of UGA were $112,658,149.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P22_S5	The management fee paid by UGA during the year amounted to $675,949.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P23_S0	In addition to the management fee, UGA pays all brokerage fees and other expenses, including tax reporting costs, licensing fees for the use of intellectual property, ongoing registration or other fees paid to the SEC, FINRA and any other regulatory agency in connection with offers and sales of its shares subsequent to the initial offering and all legal, accounting, printing and other expenses associated therewith.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P23_S1	The gross total of these fees and expenses for the year ended December 31, 2013 was $333,136, as compared to $392,438 for the year ended December 31, 2012 and $371,963 for the year ended December 31, 2011.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P23_S2	The decrease in gross total expenses excluding management fees for the year ended December 31, 2013, as compared to the year ended December 31, 2012, was due to reduced trading and reduced expected tax reporting, audit, and legal expenses during the year ended December 31, 2013 as represented by total net assets.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P23_S3	The increase in gross total expenses excluding management fees for the year ended December 31, 2012, as compared to the year ended December 31, 2011, was primarily due to an increased amortization rate for registration expenses and an increased share of directors fees and expenses being borne by UGA during the year ended December 31, 2012.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P23_S4	For the year ended December 31, 2013, UGA incurred $46,454 in ongoing registration fees and other expenses relating to the registration and offering of additional shares.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P23_S5	By comparison, for the years ended December 31, 2012 and 2011, UGA incurred $20,911 and $9,125, respectively, in ongoing registration fees and other expenses relating to the registration and offering of additional shares.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P23_S6	The increase in registration fees and expenses incurred by UGA for the year ended December 31, 2013, as compared to the year ended December 31, 2012, was primarily due to an increased amortization schedule during the year ended December 31, 2013.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P23_S7	The increase in registration fees and expenses incurred by UGA for the year ended December 31, 2012, as compared to the year ended December 31, 2011, was primarily due to an increased amortization schedule during the year ended December 31, 2012.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P23_S8	During the years ended December 31, 2013, 2012 and 2011, a voluntary expense waiver was in effect which offset certain of the expenses incurred by UGA.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P23_S9	The total amount of the expense waiver was $137,776, $139,446 and $104,053 for the years ended December 31, 2013, 2012 and 2011, respectively.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P23_S10	For the years ended December 31, 2013, 2012 and 2011, the expenses of UGA, including management fees, commissions, and all other expenses, before allowance for the expense waiver, totaled $684,313, $942,484 and $1,047,912, respectively, and after allowance for the expense waiver, totaled $546,537, $803,038, and $943,859, respectively.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P24_S0	UGA is responsible for paying its portion of the directors and officers liability insurance of UGA and the Related Public Funds and the fees and expenses of the independent directors who also serve as audit committee members of UGA and the Related Public Funds organized as limited partnerships and, as of July 8, 2011, the Related Public Funds organized as a series of a Delaware statutory trust.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P24_S1	UGA shares the fees and expenses on a pro rata basis with each Related Public Fund, as described above, based on the relative assets of each fund computed on a daily basis.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P24_S2	These fees and expenses for the year ended December 31, 2013 amounted to a total of $555,465 for UGA and the Related Public Funds.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P24_S3	UGA s portion of such fees and expenses for the year ended December 31, 2013 was $13,365.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P24_S4	By comparison, these fees and expenses for the year ended December 31, 2012 amounted to a total of $540,586 for UGA and the Related Public Funds.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P24_S5	UGA s portion of such fees and expenses for the year ended December 31, 2012 was $18,888.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P24_S6	The decrease in directors fees and expenses for the year ended December 31, 2013, as compared to the year ended December 31, 2012 was primarily due to UGA s smaller size during the year ended December 31, 2013.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P24_S7	By comparison, for the year ended December 31, 2011, these fees and expenses amounted to a total of $607,582 for UGA and the Related Public Funds.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P24_S8	UGA s portion of such fees and expenses for the year ended December 31, 2011 was $14,746.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P24_S9	The decrease in directors fees and expenses for the year ended December 31, 2012, as compared to the year ended December 31, 2011, was primarily due to the non-incurrence of the independent directors deferred compensation expense for the year ended December 31, 2012, which was amortized during the years ended December 31, 2011 and 2010.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P25_S0	UGA also incurs commissions to brokers for the purchase and sale of Futures Contracts, Other Gasoline-Related Investments or Treasuries.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P25_S1	During the year ended December 31, 2013, total commissions accrued to brokers amounted to $39,110.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P25_S2	Of this amount, approximately $37,932, or 96.99% was a result of rebalancing costs and approximately $1,178, or 3.01% was the result of trades necessitated by creation and redemption activity.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P25_S3	By comparison, during the year ended December 31, 2012, total commissions accrued to brokers amounted to $63,245.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P25_S4	Of this amount, approximately $58,167, or 91.97% was a result of rebalancing costs and approximately $5,078, or 8.03% was the result of trades necessitated by creation and redemption activity.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P25_S5	By comparison, during the year ended December 31, 2011, total commissions accrued to brokers amounted to $81,427.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P25_S6	Of this amount, approximately $76,347, or 93.76% was a result of rebalancing costs and approximately $5,080, or 6.24% was the result of trades necessitated by creation and redemption activity.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P25_S7	The decrease in the total commissions accrued to brokers for the year ended December 31, 2013, as compared to the year ended December 31, 2012, was primarily a function of a lower number of futures contracts that were held and traded as a result of UGA s reduced net assets during the year ended December 31, 2013.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P25_S8	The decrease in the total commissions accrued to brokers for the year ended December 31, 2012, as compared to the year ended December 31, 2011, was primarily a function of a lower number of futures contracts that were held and traded during the year ended December 31, 2012.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P26_S0	As an annualized percentage of average daily total net assets, the figure for the year ended December 31, 2013 represents approximately 0.07% of average daily total net assets.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P26_S1	By comparison, as an annualized percentage of average daily total net assets, the figure for the year ended December 31, 2012 represented approximately 0.07% of average daily total net assets and the figure for the year ended December 31, 2011 represented approximately 0.07% of average daily total net assets.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P26_S2	However, there can be no assurance that commission costs and portfolio turnover will not cause commission expenses to rise in future quarters.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P27_S0	The fees and expenses associated with UGA s audit expenses and tax accounting and reporting requirements are paid by UGA.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P27_S1	These costs are estimated to be $200,000 for the year ended December 31, 2013.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P27_S2	USCF has voluntarily agreed to pay certain expenses typically borne by UGA, to the extent that such expenses exceeded 0.15% (15 basis points) of UGA s NAV, on an annualized basis, through at least June 30, 2014.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P27_S3	USCF has no obligation to continue such payments into subsequent periods.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P27_S4	For the year ended December 31, 2013, USCF waived $137,776 of UGA s expenses.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P27_S5	This voluntary expense waiver is in addition to those amounts USCF is contractually obligated to pay as described in Note 4 in Item 8 of this annual report on Form 10-K.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P28_S0	UGA seeks to invest its assets such that it holds Futures Contracts and Other Gasoline-Related Investments in an amount equal to the total net assets of its portfolio.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P28_S1	Typically, such investments do not require UGA to pay the full amount of the contract value at the time of purchase, but rather require UGA to post an amount as a margin deposit against the eventual settlement of the contract.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P28_S2	As a result, UGA retains an amount that is approximately equal to its total net assets, which UGA invests in Treasuries, cash and/or cash equivalents.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P28_S3	This includes both the amount on deposit with the FCM as margin and in Treasuries, as well as unrestricted cash and cash equivalents held with UGA s Custodian.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P28_S4	The Treasuries, cash and/or cash equivalents earn income that accrues on a daily basis.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P28_S5	For the year ended December 31, 2013, UGA earned $14,479 in dividend and interest income on such Treasuries, cash and/or cash equivalents.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P28_S6	Based on UGA s average daily total net assets, this was equivalent to an annualized yield of approximately 0.02%.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P28_S7	UGA purchased Treasuries during the year ended December 31, 2013 and also held cash and/or cash equivalents during this time period.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P28_S8	By comparison, for the years ended December 31, 2012 and 2011, UGA earned $26,007 and $19,169, respectively, in dividend and interest income on such Treasuries, cash and/or cash equivalents.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P28_S9	Based on UGA s average daily total net assets, this was equivalent to an annualized yield of approximately 0.03% and 0.02%, respectively.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P28_S10	UGA purchased Treasuries during the years ended December 31, 2012 and 2011 and also held cash and/or cash equivalents during these time periods.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P28_S11	Interest rates on short-term investments held by UGA, including cash, cash equivalents and Treasuries, were similar during the year ended December 31, 2013, as compared to the year ended December 31, 2012 and similar compared to the year ended December 31, 2011.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P28_S12	As a result, the amount of income earned by UGA as a percentage of average daily total net assets was similar during the year ended December 31, 2013, as compared to the year ended December 31, 2012 and was similar as compared to the year ended December 31, 2011.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P29_S0	During the three months ended December 31, 2013, the average daily total net assets of UGA were $55,178,214.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P29_S1	The management fee incurred by UGA during the period amounted to $83,448.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P29_S2	By comparison, during the three months ended December 31, 2012, the average daily total net assets of UGA were $64,456,487.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P29_S3	The management fee paid by UGA during the period amounted to $97,214.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P29_S4	By comparison, during the three months ended December 31, 2011, the average daily total net assets of UGA were $77,734,009.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P29_S5	The management fee paid by UGA during the period amounted to $117,560.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P30_S0	In addition to the management fee, UGA pays all brokerage fees and other expenses, including tax reporting costs, licensing fees for the use of intellectual property, ongoing registration or other fees paid to the SEC, FINRA and any other regulatory agency in connection with offers and sales of its shares subsequent to the initial offering and all legal, accounting, printing and other expenses associated therewith.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P30_S1	The gross total of these fees and expenses for the three months ended December 31, 2013 was $63,128, as compared to $119,329 for the three months ended December 31, 2012 and $23,791 for the three months ended December 31, 2011.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P30_S2	The decrease in gross total expenses excluding management fees for the three months ended December 31, 2013 as compared to the three months ended December 31, 2012, was primarily due to UGA s smaller size during the three months ended December 31, 2013, as represented by total net assets.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P30_S3	The increase in gross total expenses excluding management fees for the three months ended December 31, 2012 as compared to the three months ended December 31, 2011, was primarily due to UGA s increased audit and tax reporting expenses during the three months ended December 31, 2012.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P30_S4	For the three months ended December 31, 2013, UGA incurred $11,709 in ongoing registration fees and other expenses relating to the registration and offering of additional shares.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P30_S5	By comparison, for the three months ended December 31, 2012 and 2011, UGA incurred $11,709 and $2,300, respectively, in ongoing registration fees and other expenses relating to the registration and offering of additional shares.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P30_S6	The registration fees and expenses incurred by UGA for the three months ended December 31, 2013 and 2012 were the same.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P30_S7	The increase in registration fees and expenses incurred by UGA for the three months ended December 31, 2012, as compared to the three months ended December 31, 2011, was primarily due to an increased amortization schedule during the three months ended December 31, 2012.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P30_S8	During the three months ended December 31, 2013, 2012 and 2011, a voluntary expense waiver was in effect to offset certain of the expenses incurred by UGA.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P30_S9	During the three months ended December 31, 2011, UGA s expenses did not exceed 0.15% (15 basis points) of its NAV; therefore, no expenses were waived by USCF.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P30_S10	During the three months ended December 31, 2013 and 2012, the total amount of the expense waiver was $16,030 and $64,418, respectively.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P30_S11	For the three months ended December 31, 2013 and 2012, the expenses of UGA, including management fees, commissions, and all other expenses, before allowance for the expense waiver, totaled $146,576 and $216,543, respectively, and after allowance for the expense waiver, totaled $130,546 and $152,125, respectively.

1396878_14_ITEM7_P31_S1	UGA shares the fees and expenses on a pro rata basis with each Related Public Fund, as described above, based on the relative assets of each fund computed on a daily basis.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P31_S2	These fees and expenses for the year ended December 31, 2013 amounted to a total of $555,465 for UGA and the Related Public Funds.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P31_S3	UGA s portion of such fees and expenses for the year ended December 31, 2013 was $13,365.

1396878_14_ITEM7_P32_S6	Of this amount, approximately $14,330, or 95.21% was a result of rebalancing costs and approximately $721, or 4.79% was the result of trades necessitated by creation and redemption activity.

1396878_14_ITEM7_P32_S10	By comparison, the figure for the three months ended December 31, 2012 represented approximately 0.07% of average daily total net assets and the figure for the three months ended December 31, 2011 represented approximately 0.08% of average daily total net assets.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P32_S11	However, there can be no assurance that commission costs and portfolio turnover will not cause commission expenses to rise in future quarters.

1396878_14_ITEM7_P33_S3	USCF has no obligation to continue such payments into subsequent periods.

1396878_14_ITEM7_P34_S0	UGA seeks to invest its assets such that it holds Futures Contracts and Other Gasoline-Related Investments in an amount equal to the total net assets of its portfolio.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P34_S1	Typically, such investments do not require UGA to pay the full amount of the contract value at the time of purchase, but rather require UGA to post an amount as a margin deposit against the eventual settlement of the contract.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P34_S2	As a result, UGA retains an amount that is approximately equal to its total net assets, which UGA invests in Treasuries, cash and/or cash equivalents.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P34_S3	This includes both the amount on deposit with the FCM as margin and in Treasuries, as well as unrestricted cash and cash equivalents held with UGA s Custodian.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P34_S4	The Treasuries, cash and/or cash equivalents earn income that accrues on a daily basis.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P34_S5	For the three months ended December 31, 2013, UGA earned $3,398 in dividend and interest income on such Treasuries, cash and/or cash equivalents.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P34_S6	Based on UGA s average daily total net assets, this was equivalent to an annualized yield of approximately 0.02%.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P34_S7	UGA purchased Treasuries during the three months ended December 31, 2013 and also held cash and/or cash equivalents during this time period.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P34_S8	By comparison, for the three months ended December 31, 2012 and 2011, UGA earned $6,031and $3,851, respectively in dividend and interest income on such Treasuries, cash and/or cash equivalents.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P34_S9	Based on UGA s average daily total net assets, this was equivalent to an annualized yield of approximately 0.04% and 0.02, respectively.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P34_S10	UGA purchased Treasuries during the three months ended December 31, 2012 and 2011 and also held cash and/or cash equivalents during these time periods.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P34_S11	Interest rates on short-term investments held by UGA, including cash, cash equivalents and Treasuries, were similar during the three months ended December 31, 2013 compared to the three months ended December 31, 2012 and similar compared to the three months ended December 31, 2011.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P34_S12	As a result, the amount of income earned by UGA as a percentage of average daily total net assets was similar during the three months ended December 31, 2013 as compared to the three months ended December 31, 2012 and was similar as compared to the three months ended December 31, 2011.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P35_S0	USCF seeks to manage UGA s portfolio such that average daily changes in its per share NAV, on a percentage basis, closely track the average daily changes in the price of the Benchmark Futures Contract, also on a percentage basis.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P35_S1	Specifically, USCF seeks to manage the portfolio such that over any rolling period of 30 valuation days, the average daily change in UGA s per share NAV is within a range of 90% to 110% (0.9 to 1.1) of the average daily change in the price of the Benchmark Futures Contract.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P35_S2	As an example, if the average daily movement of the price of the Benchmark Futures Contract for a particular 30-valuation day time period was 0.5% per day, USCF would attempt to manage the portfolio such that the average daily movement of the per share NAV during that same time period fell between 0.45% and 0.55% ( i.e ., between 0.9 and 1.1 of the benchmark s results).
1396878_14_ITEM7_P35_S3	UGA s portfolio management goals do not include trying to make the nominal price of UGA s per share NAV equal to the nominal price of the current Benchmark Futures Contract or the spot price for gasoline.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P35_S4	USCF believes that it is not practical to manage the portfolio to achieve such an investment goal when investing in listed gasoline Futures Contracts.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P36_S0	For the 30 valuation days ended December 31, 2013, the simple average daily change in the Benchmark Futures Contract was 0.172%, while the simple average daily change in the per share NAV of UGA over the same time period was 0.167%.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P36_S1	The average daily difference was (0.004)% (or (0.4) basis points, where 1 basis point equals 1/100 of 1%).
1396878_14_ITEM7_P36_S2	As a percentage of the daily movement of the Benchmark Futures Contract, the average error in daily tracking by the per share NAV was (1.604)%, meaning that over this time period UGA s tracking error was within the plus or minus 10% range established as its benchmark tracking goal.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P36_S3	The first chart below shows the daily movement of UGA s per share NAV versus the daily movement of the Benchmark Futures Contract for the 30-valuation day period ended December 31, 2013, the last trading day in December.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P36_S4	The second chart below shows the monthly total returns of UGA as compared to the monthly value of the Benchmark Futures Contract for the five years ended December 31, 2013.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P37_S0	Since the commencement of the offering of UGA shares to the public on February 26, 2008 to December 31, 2013, the simple average daily change in the Benchmark Futures Contract was 0.042%, while the simple average daily change in the per share NAV of UGA over the same time period was 0.039%.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P37_S1	The average daily difference was (0.003)% (or (0.3) basis points, where 1 basis point equals 1/100 of 1%).
1396878_14_ITEM7_P37_S2	As a percentage of the daily movement of the Benchmark Futures Contract, the average error in daily tracking by the per share NAV was (0.977)%, meaning that over this time period UGA s tracking error was within the plus or minus 10% range established as its benchmark tracking goal.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P38_S0	An alternative tracking measurement of the return performance of UGA versus the return of its Benchmark Futures Contract can be calculated by comparing the actual return of UGA, measured by changes in its per share NAV, versus the expected changes in its per share NAV under the assumption that UGA s returns had been exactly the same as the daily changes in its Benchmark Futures Contract.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P39_S0	For the year ended December 31, 2013, the actual total return of UGA as measured by changes in its per share NAV was 2.57%.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P39_S1	This is based on an initial per share NAV of $58.39 on December 31, 2012 and an ending per share NAV as of December 31, 2013 of $58.39.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P39_S2	During this time period, UGA made no distributions to its shareholders.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P39_S3	However, if UGA s daily changes in its per share NAV had instead exactly tracked the changes in the daily total return of the Benchmark Futures Contract, UGA would have had an estimated per share NAV of $60.46 as of December 31, 2013, for a total return over the relevant time period of 3.54%.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P39_S4	The difference between the actual per share NAV total return of UGA of 2.57% and the expected total return based on the Benchmark Futures Contract of 3.54% was an error over the time period of (0.97)%, which is to say that UGA s actual total return underperformed the benchmark result by that percentage.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P39_S5	USCF believes that a portion of the difference between the actual total return and the expected benchmark total return can be attributed to the net impact of the expenses that UGA pays, offset in part by the income that UGA collects on its cash and cash equivalent holdings.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P40_S0	During the year ended December 31, 2013, UGA earned dividend and interest income of $14,479, which is equivalent to a weighted average income rate of approximately 0.02% for such period.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P40_S1	In addition, during the year ended December 31, 2013, UGA also collected $5,600 from its Authorized Purchasers for creating or redeeming baskets of shares.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P40_S2	This income also contributed to UGA s actual total return.

1396878_14_ITEM7_P41_S0	By comparison, for the year ended December 31, 2012, the actual total return of UGA as measured by changes in its per share NAV was 20.72%.

1396878_14_ITEM7_P41_S4	The difference between the actual per share NAV total return of UGA of 20.72% and the expected total return based on the Benchmark Futures Contract of 21.75% was an error over the time period of (1.03)%, which is to say that UGA s actual total return underperformed the benchmark result by that percentage.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P41_S5	USCF believes that a portion of the difference between the actual total return and the expected benchmark total return can be attributed to the net impact of the expenses that UGA paid, offset in part by the income that UGA collected on its cash and cash equivalent holdings.

1396878_14_ITEM7_P42_S0	By comparison, for the year ended December 31, 2011, the actual total return of UGA as measured by changes in its per share NAV was 15.00%.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P42_S1	This was based on an initial per share NAV of $42.06 on December 31, 2010 and an ending per share NAV as of December 31, 2011 of $48.37.

1396878_14_ITEM7_P42_S4	The difference between the actual per share NAV total return of UGA of 15.00% and the expected total return based on the Benchmark Futures Contract of 15.93% was an error over the time period of (0.93)%, which is to say that UGA s actual total return underperformed the benchmark result by that percentage.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P42_S5	USCF believes that a portion of the difference between the actual total return and the expected benchmark total return can be attributed to the net impact of the expenses that UGA paid, offset in part by the income that UGA collected on its cash and cash equivalent holdings.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P42_S6	In addition, during the year ended December 31, 2011, UGA earned dividend and interest income of $19,169, which is equivalent to a weighted average income rate of approximately 0.02% for such period.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P42_S7	In addition, during the year ended December 31, 2011, UGA also collected $26,200 from its Authorized Purchasers for creating or redeeming baskets of shares.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P42_S8	This income also contributed to UGA s actual total return.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P42_S9	During the year ended December 31, 2011, UGA incurred net expenses of $943,859.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P42_S10	Income from dividends and interest and Authorized Purchaser collections net of expenses was $(898,490), which is equivalent to a weighted average net income rate of approximately (0.80)% for the year ended December 31, 2011.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P43_S0	There are currently three factors that have impacted or are most likely to impact UGA s ability to accurately track its Benchmark Futures Contract.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P44_S0	First, UGA may buy or sell its holdings in the then current Benchmark Futures Contract at a price other than the closing settlement price of that contract on the day during which UGA executes the trade.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P44_S1	In that case, UGA may pay a price that is higher, or lower, than that of the Benchmark Futures Contract, which could cause the daily changes in the per share NAV of UGA to either be too high or too low relative to the daily changes in the Benchmark Futures Contract.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P45_S0	During the year ended December 31, 2013, USCF attempted to minimize the effect of these transactions by seeking to execute its purchase or sale of the Benchmark Futures Contract at, or as close as possible to, the end of the day settlement price.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P45_S1	However, it may not always be possible for UGA to obtain the closing settlement price and there is no assurance that failure to obtain the closing settlement price in the future will not adversely impact UGA s attempt to track the Benchmark Futures Contract over time.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P46_S0	Second, UGA earns dividend and interest income on its cash, cash equivalents and Treasuries.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P46_S1	UGA is not required to distribute any portion of its income to its shareholders and did not make any distributions to shareholders during the year ended December 31, 2013.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P46_S2	Interest payments, and any other income, were retained within the portfolio and added to UGA s NAV.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P46_S3	When this income exceeds the level of UGA s expenses for its management fee, brokerage commissions and other expenses (including ongoing registration fees, licensing fees and the fees and expenses of the independent directors of USCF), UGA will realize a net yield that will tend to cause daily changes in the per share NAV of UGA to track slightly higher than daily changes in the Benchmark Futures Contract.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P47_S0	During the year ended December 31, 2013, UGA earned, on an annualized basis, approximately 0.02% on its cash and cash equivalent holdings.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P47_S1	It also incurred cash expenses on an annualized basis of (0.60)% for management fees, approximately (0.07)% in brokerage commission costs related to the purchase and sale of futures contracts, and approximately (0.27)% for other net expenses.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P47_S2	The foregoing fees and expenses resulted in a net yield on an annualized basis of approximately (0.90)% and affected UGA s ability to track its benchmark.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P48_S0	If short-term interest rates rise above the current levels, the level of deviation created by the yield would decrease.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P48_S1	Conversely, if short-term interest rates were to decline, the amount of error created by the yield would increase.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P48_S2	When short-term yields drop to a level lower than the combined expenses of the management fee and the brokerage commissions, then the tracking error becomes a negative number and would tend to cause the daily returns of the per share NAV to underperform the daily returns of the Benchmark Futures Contract.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P48_S3	USCF anticipates that interest rates will continue to remain at historical lows and, therefore, it is anticipated that fees and expenses paid by UGA will continue to be higher than interest earned by UGA.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P48_S4	As such, USCF anticipates that UGA will continue to underperform its benchmark until such time when interest earned at least equals or exceeds the fees and expenses paid by UGA.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P49_S0	Third, UGA may hold Other Gasoline-Related Investments in its portfolio that may fail to closely track the Benchmark Futures Contract s total return movements.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P49_S1	In that case, the error in tracking the Benchmark Futures Contract could result in daily changes in the per share NAV of UGA that are either too high, or too low, relative to the daily changes in the Benchmark Futures Contract.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P49_S2	During the year ended December 31, 2013, UGA did not hold any Other Gasoline-Related Investments.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P49_S3	If UGA increases in size, and due to its obligations to comply with regulatory limits, UGA may invest in Other Gasoline-Related Investments which may have the effect of increasing transaction related expenses and may result in increased tracking error.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P50_S0	Term Structure of Gasoline Futures Prices and the Impact on Total Returns.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P51_S0	Several factors determine the total return from investing in a futures contract position.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P51_S1	One factor that impacts the total return that will result from investing in near month futures contracts and rolling those contracts forward each month is the price relationship between the current near month contract and the next month contract.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P51_S2	For example, if the price of the near month contract is higher than the next month contract (a situation referred to as backwardation in the futures market), then absent any other change there is a tendency for the price of a next month contract to rise in value as it becomes the near month contract and approaches expiration.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P51_S3	Conversely, if the price of a near month contract is lower than the next month contract (a situation referred to as contango in the futures market), then absent any other change there is a tendency for the price of a next month contract to decline in value as it becomes the near month contract and approaches expiration.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P52_S0	As an example, assume that the price of gasoline for immediate delivery (the spot price), was $2 per gallon, and the value of a position in the near month futures contract was also $2.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P53_S0	Over time, the price of a gallon of gasoline will fluctuate based on a number of market factors, including demand for gasoline relative to its supply.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P53_S1	The value of the near month contract will likewise fluctuate in reaction to a number of market factors.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P53_S2	If investors seek to maintain their position in a near month contract and not take delivery of the gasoline, every month they must sell their current near month contract as it approaches expiration and invest in the next month contract.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P54_S0	If the futures market is in backwardation, e.g. , when the expected price of gasoline in the future would be less, the investor would be buying a next month contract for a lower price than the current near month contract.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P54_S1	Using the $2 per gallon price above to represent the front month price, the price of the next month contract could be $1.96 per barrel, that is, 2% cheaper than the front month contract.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P54_S2	Hypothetically, and assuming no other changes to either prevailing gasoline prices or the price relationship between the spot price, the near month contract and the next month contract (and ignoring the impact of commission costs and the income earned on cash and/or cash equivalents), the value of the $1.96 next month contract would rise as it approaches expiration and becomes the new near month contract with a price of $2.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P54_S3	In this example, the value of an investment in the second month contract would tend to rise faster than the spot price of gasoline, or fall slower.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P54_S4	As a result, it would be possible in this hypothetical example for the spot price of gasoline to have risen 10% after some period of time, while the value of the investment in the second month futures contract would have risen 12%, assuming backwardation is large enough or enough time has elapsed.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P54_S5	Similarly, the spot price of gasoline could have fallen 10% while the value of an investment in the futures contract could have fallen only 8%.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P54_S6	Over time, if backwardation remained constant, the difference would continue to increase.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P55_S0	If the futures market is in contango, the investor would be buying a next month contract for a higher price than the current near month contract.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P55_S1	Using again the $2 per gallon price above to represent the front month price, the price of the next month contract could be $2.04 per barrel, that is, 2% more expensive than the front month contract.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P55_S2	Hypothetically, and assuming no other changes to either prevailing gasoline prices or the price relationship between the spot price, the near month contract and the next month contract (and ignoring the impact of commission costs and the income earned on cash and/or cash equivalents), the value of the next month contract would fall as it approaches expiration and becomes the new near month contract with a price of $2.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P55_S3	In this example, it would mean that the value of an investment in the second month would tend to rise slower than the spot price of gasoline, or fall faster.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P55_S4	As a result, it would be possible in this hypothetical example for the spot price of gasoline to have risen 10% after some period of time, while the value of the investment in the second month futures contract will have risen only 8%, assuming contango is large enough or enough time has elapsed.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P55_S5	Similarly, the spot price of gasoline could have fallen 10% while the value of an investment in the second month futures contract could have fallen 12%.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P55_S6	Over time, if contango remained constant, the difference would continue to increase.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P56_S0	The chart below compares the price of the near month contract to the price of the next month contract over the last 10 years for gasoline.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P56_S1	When the price of the near month contract is higher than the price of the next month contract, the market would be described as being in backwardation.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P56_S2	When the price of the near month contract is lower than the price of the next month contract, the market would be described as being in contango.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P56_S3	Although the prices of the near month contract and the price of the next month contract do tend to move up or down together, it can be seen that at times the near month prices are clearly higher than the price of the next month contract (backwardation), and other times they are below the price of the next month contract (contango).
1396878_14_ITEM7_P56_S4	In addition, investors can observe that gasoline prices, both near month and next month, often display a seasonal pattern in which the price of gasoline tends to rise in the summer months and decline in the winter months.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P56_S5	This mirrors the physical demand for gasoline, which typically peaks in the summer.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P57_S0	An alternative way to view backwardation and contango data over time is to subtract the dollar price of the next month gasoline futures contract from the dollar price of the near month gasoline futures contract.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P57_S1	If the resulting number is a positive number, then the price of the near month contract is higher than the price of the next month and the market could be described as being in backwardation.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P57_S2	If the resulting number is a negative number, then the near month price is lower than the price of the next month and the market could be described as being in contango.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P58_S0	The chart below shows the results from subtracting the next month contract price from the price of the near month contract for the 10 year period between December 31, 2003 and December 31, 2013.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P58_S1	Investors will note that the near month gasoline futures contract spent time in both backwardation and contango.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P58_S2	Investors will further note that the markets display a very seasonal pattern that corresponds to the seasonal demand patterns for gasoline mentioned above.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P58_S3	That is, in many, but not all cases, the price of the near month is higher than the next month during the middle of the summer months as the price of gasoline for delivery in those summer months rises to meet peak demand.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P58_S4	At the same time, the price of the near month contract, when that month is just before the onset of spring, does not rise as far or as fast as the price of a next month contract whose delivery falls closer to the start of the summer season.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P59_S0	While the investment objective of UGA is not to have the market price of its shares match, dollar for dollar, changes in the spot price of gasoline, contango and backwardation have impacted the total return on an investment in UGA shares during the past year relative to a hypothetical direct investment in gasoline.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P59_S1	For example, an investment in UGA shares made on December 31, 2012 and held to December 31, 2013 increased based upon the changes in the NAV for UGA shares on those days, by approximately 2.57%, while the spot price of gasoline for immediate delivery during the same period increased by 0.88% (note: this comparison ignores the potential costs associated with physically owning and storing gasoline, which could be substantial).
1396878_14_ITEM7_P59_S2	By comparison, an investment in UGA shares made on December 31, 2011 and held to December 31, 2012 increased based upon the changes in the NAV for UGA shares on those days, by approximately 20.72%, while the spot price of gasoline for immediate delivery during the same period increased by 3.92% (note: this comparison ignores the potential costs associated with physically owning and storing gasoline, which could be substantial).
1396878_14_ITEM7_P60_S0	Periods of contango or backwardation do not materially impact UGA s investment objective of having the daily percentage changes in its per share NAV track the daily percentage changes in the price of the Benchmark Futures Contract since the impact of backwardation and contango tend to equally impact the daily percentage changes in price of both UGA s shares and the Benchmark Futures Contract.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P61_S0	It is impossible to predict with any degree of certainty whether backwardation or contango will occur in the future.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P61_S1	It is likely that both conditions will occur during different periods.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P62_S0	During the year ended December 31, 2013, the price of unleaded gasoline in the United States was impacted by several factors.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P62_S1	In particular, USCF believes that rising crude oil prices in the United States were partially offset by resolution of refinery maintenance issues towards the end of September 2013, resulting in gasoline prices that concluded the year up only a moderate amount.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P63_S0	The price of the Benchmark Futures Contract began 2013 at $2.7617 per gallon.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P63_S1	Prices rose sharply over the course of the year and hit a peak on February 19, 2013 of $3.3152 per gallon.
1396878_14_ITEM7_P63_S2	The low for the year was on November 7, 2013, when the price dropped to $2.5031 per gallon.
