1396878_17_ITEM8_P15_S0	* Collateral amounted to $2,277,668 on open futures contracts.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P16_S0	See accompanying notes to financial statements.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P17_S0	* Collateral amounted to $11,076,293 on open futures contracts.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P18_S0	See accompanying notes to financial statements.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P19_S0	See accompanying notes to financial statements.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P20_S0	See accompanying notes to financial statements.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P21_S0	See accompanying notes to financial statements.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P22_S0	The United States Gasoline Fund, LP ( UGA ) was organized as a limited partnership under the laws of the state of Delaware on April 13, 2007.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P22_S1	UGA is a commodity pool that issues limited partnership shares ( shares ) that may be purchased and sold on the NYSE Arca, Inc. (the NYSE Arca ).
1396878_17_ITEM8_P22_S2	Prior to November 25, 2008, UGA s shares traded on the American Stock Exchange (the AMEX ).
1396878_17_ITEM8_P22_S3	UGA will continue in perpetuity, unless terminated sooner upon the occurrence of one or more events as described in its Second Amended and Restated Agreement of Limited Partnership dated as of March 1, 2013 (the LP Agreement ).
1396878_17_ITEM8_P23_S0	The investment objective of UGA is for the daily changes in percentage terms of its shares per share net asset value ( NAV ) to reflect the daily changes in percentage terms of the spot price of gasoline (also known as reformulated gasoline blendstock for oxygen blending, or RBOB , for delivery to the New York harbor), as measured by the daily changes in the price of the futures contract for gasoline traded on the New York Mercantile Exchange (the NYMEX ) that is the near month contract to expire, except when the near month contract is within two weeks of expiration, in which case the futures contract will be the next month contract to expire (the Benchmark Futures Contract ), plus interest earned on UGA s collateral holdings, less UGA s expenses.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P23_S1	It is not the intent of UGA to be operated in a fashion such that the per share NAV will equal, in dollar terms, the spot price of gasoline or any particular futures contract based on gasoline, nor is UGA s investment objective for the percentage change in its per share NAV to reflect the percentage change of the price of any particular futures contract as measured over a time period greater than one day.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P23_S2	United States Commodity Funds LLC ( USCF ), the general partner of UGA, believes that it is not practical to manage the portfolio to achieve such an investment goal when investing in Futures Contracts (as defined below) and Other Gasoline-Related Investments (as defined below).
1396878_17_ITEM8_P24_S0	UGA accomplishes its objective through investments primarily in futures contracts for gasoline, crude oil, natural gas, diesel-heating oil and other petroleum-based fuels that are traded on the NYMEX, ICE Futures or other U.S. and foreign exchanges (collectively, Futures Contracts ) and to a lesser extent, in order to comply with regulatory requirements or in view of market conditions, other gasoline-related investments such as cash-settled options on Futures Contracts, forward contracts for gasoline, cleared swap contracts and over-the-counter ( OTC ) transactions that are based on the price of gasoline, crude oil and other petroleum-based fuels, Futures Contracts and indices based on the foregoing (collectively, Other Gasoline-Related Investments ).
1396878_17_ITEM8_P24_S1	As of December 31, 2016, UGA held 1,006 Futures Contracts for gasoline traded on the NYMEX and did not hold any Futures Contracts traded on ICE Futures.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P25_S0	UGA commenced investment operations on February 26, 2008 and has a fiscal year ending on December 31.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P25_S1	USCF is responsible for the management of UGA.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P26_S0	USCF is a member of the National Futures Association (the NFA ) and became registered as a commodity pool operator with the Commodity Futures Trading Commission (the CFTC ) effective December 1, 2005 and a swaps firm on August 8, 2013.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P26_S1	USCF is also the general partner of the United States Oil Fund, LP ( USO ), the United States Natural Gas Fund, LP ( UNG ), the United States 12 Month Oil Fund, LP ( USL ) and the United States Diesel-Heating Oil Fund, LP ( UHN ), which listed their limited partnership shares on the AMEX under the ticker symbols USO on April 10, 2006, UNG on April 18, 2007, USL on December 6, 2007 and UHN on April 9, 2008, respectively.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P26_S2	As a result of the acquisition of the AMEX by NYSE Euronext, each of USO s, UNG s, USL s and UHN s shares commenced trading on the NYSE Arca on November 25, 2008.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P26_S3	USCF is also the general partner of the United States Short Oil Fund, LP ( DNO ), the United States 12 Month Natural Gas Fund, LP ( UNL ) and the United States Brent Oil Fund, LP ( BNO ), which listed their limited partnership shares on the NYSE Arca under the ticker symbols DNO on September 24, 2009, UNL on November 18, 2009 and BNO on June 2, 2010, respectively.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P26_S4	USCF is also the sponsor of the United States Commodity Index Fund ( USCI ), the United States Copper Index Fund ( CPER ), the United States Agriculture Index Fund ( USAG ) and the USCF Canadian Crude Oil Index Fund ( UCCO ), each a series of the United States Commodity Index Funds Trust.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P26_S5	USCI, CPER and USAG listed their shares on the NYSE Arca under the ticker symbol USCI on August 10, 2010, CPER on November 15, 2011 and USAG on April 13, 2012, respectively.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P27_S0	All funds listed previously, other than UCCO, are referred to collectively herein as the Related Public Funds.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P28_S0	In addition, USCF is the sponsor of the USCF Funds Trust, a Delaware statutory trust, and each of its series, the REX S P MLP Fund, the REX S P MLP Inverse Fund, the United States 3X Oil Fund and the United States 3X Short Oil Fund, all of which are funds that are currently in registration and have not commenced operations.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P28_S1	The funds that are series of the USCF Funds Trust (the REX Funds ) are not included in the Related Public Funds.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P29_S0	UGA issues shares to certain Authorized Participants ( Authorized Participants ) by offering baskets consisting of 50,000 shares ( Creation Baskets ) through ALPS Distributors, Inc., as the marketing agent (the Marketing Agent ).
1396878_17_ITEM8_P29_S1	The purchase price for a Creation Basket is based upon the NAV of a share calculated shortly after the close of the core trading session on the NYSE Arca on the day the order to create the basket is properly received.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P30_S0	From July 1, 2011 and continuing at least through April 30, 2017, the applicable transaction fee paid by Authorized Participants is $350 to UGA for each order they place to create or redeem one or more baskets ( Redemption Baskets ); prior to July 1, 2011, this fee was $1,000.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P30_S1	Shares may be purchased or sold on a nationally recognized securities exchange in smaller increments than a Creation Basket or Redemption Basket.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P30_S2	Shares purchased or sold on a nationally recognized securities exchange are not purchased or sold at the per share NAV of UGA but rather at market prices quoted on such exchange.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P31_S0	In November 2007, UGA initially registered 30,000,000 shares on Form S-1 with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission ( the SEC ).
1396878_17_ITEM8_P31_S1	On February 26, 2008, UGA listed its shares on the AMEX under the ticker symbol UGA and switched to trading on the NYSE Arca under the same ticker symbol on November 25, 2008.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P31_S2	On that day, UGA established its initial per share NAV by setting the price at $50.00 and issued 300,000 shares in exchange for $15,000,000.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P31_S3	UGA also commenced investment operations on February 26, 2008, by purchasing Futures Contracts traded on the NYMEX based on gasoline.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P31_S4	As of December 31, 2016, UGA had registered a total of 80,000,000 shares.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P32_S0	The financial statements have been prepared in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America ( U.S. GAAP ) as detailed in the Financial Accounting Standards Board s ( FASB ) Accounting Standards Codification.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P32_S1	UGA is an investment company and follows the accounting and reporting guidance in FASB Topic 946.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P33_S0	Commodity futures contracts, forward contracts, physical commodities, and related options are recorded on the trade date.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P33_S1	All such transactions are recorded on the identified cost basis and marked to market daily.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P34_S0	Unrealized gains or losses on open contracts are reflected in the statements of financial condition and represent the difference between the original contract amount and the market value (as determined by exchange settlement prices for futures contracts and related options and cash dealer prices at a predetermined time for forward contracts, physical commodities, and their related options) as of the last business day of the year or as of the last date of the financial statements.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P34_S1	Changes in the unrealized gains or losses between periods are reflected in the statements of operations.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P35_S0	UGA earns income on funds held at the custodian or futures commission merchant ( FCM ) at prevailing market rates earned on such investments.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P36_S0	Brokerage commissions on all open commodity futures contracts are accrued on a full-turn basis.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P37_S0	UGA is not subject to federal income taxes; each partner reports his/her allocable share of income, gain, loss deductions or credits on his/her own income tax return.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P38_S0	In accordance with U.S. GAAP, UGA is required to determine whether a tax position is more likely than not to be sustained upon examination by the applicable taxing authority, including resolution of any tax related appeals or litigation processes, based on the technical merits of the position.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P39_S0	UGA files an income tax return in the U.S. federal jurisdiction, and may file income tax returns in various U.S. states.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P39_S1	UGA is not subject to income tax return examinations by major taxing authorities for years before 2013.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P39_S2	The tax benefit recognized is measured as the largest amount of benefit that has a greater than fifty percent likelihood of being realized upon ultimate settlement.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P39_S3	De-recognition of a tax benefit previously recognized results in UGA recording a tax liability that reduces net assets.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P39_S4	However, UGA s conclusions regarding this policy may be subject to review and adjustment at a later date based on factors including, but not limited to, on-going analysis of and changes to tax laws, regulations and interpretations thereof.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P40_S0	UGA recognizes interest accrued related to unrecognized tax benefits and penalties related to unrecognized tax benefits in income tax fees payable, if assessed.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P40_S1	No interest expense or penalties have been recognized as of and for the year ended December 31, 2016.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P41_S0	Authorized Participants may purchase Creation Baskets or redeem Redemption Baskets only in blocks of 50,000 shares at a price equal to the NAV of the shares calculated shortly after the close of the core trading session on the NYSE Arca on the day the order is placed.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P42_S0	UGA receives or pays the proceeds from shares sold or redeemed within three business days after the trade date of the purchase or redemption.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P42_S1	The amounts due from Authorized Participants are reflected in UGA s statements of financial condition as receivable for shares sold, and amounts payable to Authorized Participants upon redemption are reflected as payable for shares redeemed.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P43_S0	Authorized Participants pay UGA a transaction fee of $350 for each order placed to create one or more Creation Baskets or to redeem one or more Redemption Baskets.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P44_S0	Profit or loss shall be allocated among the partners of UGA in proportion to the number of shares each partner holds as of the close of each month.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P44_S1	USCF may revise, alter or otherwise modify this method of allocation as described in the LP Agreement.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P45_S0	UGA s per share NAV is calculated on each NYSE Arca trading day by taking the current market value of its total assets, subtracting any liabilities and dividing that amount by the total number of shares outstanding.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P45_S1	UGA uses the closing price for the contracts on the relevant exchange on that day to determine the value of contracts held on such exchange.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P46_S0	Net income (loss) per share is the difference between the per share NAV at the beginning of each period and at the end of each period.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P46_S1	The weighted average number of shares outstanding was computed for purposes of disclosing net income (loss) per weighted average share.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P46_S2	The weighted average shares are equal to the number of shares outstanding at the end of the period, adjusted proportionately for shares added and redeemed based on the amount of time the shares were outstanding during such period.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P46_S3	There were no shares held by USCF at December 31, 2016.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P47_S0	Offering costs incurred in connection with the registration of additional shares after the initial registration of shares are borne by UGA.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P47_S1	These costs include registration fees paid to regulatory agencies and all legal, accounting, printing and other expenses associated with such offerings.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P47_S2	These costs are accounted for as a deferred charge and thereafter amortized to expense over twelve months on a straight-line basis or a shorter period if warranted.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P48_S0	Cash equivalents include money market funds and overnight deposits or time deposits with original maturity dates of six months or less.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P49_S0	Certain amounts in the accompanying financial statements were reclassified to conform to the current presentation.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P50_S0	The preparation of financial statements in conformity with U.S. GAAP requires USCF to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amount of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements, and the reported amounts of the revenue and expenses during the reporting period.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P50_S1	Actual results may differ from those estimates and assumptions.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P51_S0	Under the LP Agreement, USCF is responsible for investing the assets of UGA in accordance with the objectives and policies of UGA.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P51_S1	In addition, USCF has arranged for one or more third parties to provide administrative, custody, accounting, transfer agency and other necessary services to UGA.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P51_S2	For these services, UGA is contractually obligated to pay USCF a fee, which is paid monthly, equal to 0.60% per annum of average daily total net assets.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P52_S0	UGA pays all costs and expenses associated with the ongoing registration of its shares subsequent to the initial offering.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P52_S1	These costs include registration or other fees paid to regulatory agencies in connection with the offer and sale of shares, and all legal, accounting, printing and other expenses associated with such offer and sale.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P52_S2	For the years ended December 31, 2016, 2015 and 2014, UGA incurred $46,581, $46,453 and $46,454, respectively, in registration fees and other offering expenses.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P53_S0	UGA is responsible for paying its portion of the directors and officers liability insurance for UGA and the Related Public Funds and the fees and expenses of the independent directors who also serve as audit committee members of UGA and the Related Public Funds.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P53_S1	UGA shares the fees and expenses on a pro rata basis with each Related Public Fund, as described above, based on the relative assets of each fund computed on a daily basis.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P53_S2	These fees and expenses for the year ended December 31, 2016 were $582,050 for UGA and the Related Public Funds.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P53_S3	UGA s portion of such fees and expenses for the year ended December 31, 2016 was $10,319.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P53_S4	For the year ended December 31, 2015, these fees and expenses were $569,303 for UGA and the Related Public Funds.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P53_S5	UGA s portion of such fees and expenses for the year ended December 31, 2015 was $10,840.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P53_S6	For the year ended December 31, 2014, these fees and expenses were $567,863 for UGA and the Related Public Funds.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P53_S7	UGA s portion of such fees and expenses for the year ended December 31, 2014 was $12,396.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P54_S0	As discussed in Note 4 below, UGA entered into a licensing agreement with the NYMEX on April 10, 2006, as amended on October 20, 2011.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P54_S1	Pursuant to the agreement, UGA and the Related Public Funds, other than BNO, USCI, CPER and USAG, pay a licensing fee that is equal to 0.015% on all net assets.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P54_S2	During the years ended December 31, 2016, 2015 and 2014, UGA incurred $11,052, $12,365 and $7,357, respectively, under this arrangement.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P55_S0	The fees and expenses associated with UGA s audit expenses and tax accounting and reporting requirements are paid by UGA.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P55_S1	These costs were approximately $178,000, $164,000 and $164,000, respectively, for the years ended December 31, 2016, 2015 and 2014.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P55_S2	Tax report costs fluctuate between years due to the number of shareholders during any given year.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P56_S0	In addition to the fees described above, UGA pays all brokerage fees and other expenses in connection with the operation of UGA, excluding costs and expenses paid by USCF as outlined in Note 4 below.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P56_S1	USCF paid certain expenses typically borne by UGA on a discretionary basis where expenses exceeded 0.15% (15 basis points) of UGA s NAV, on an annualized basis.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P56_S2	USCF has no obligation to continue such payments into subsequent periods.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P56_S3	For the year ended December 31, 2016, USCF waived $269,909 of UGA s expenses.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P56_S4	This voluntary expense waiver is in addition to those amounts USCF is contractually obligated to pay as described in Note 4 Contracts and Agreements below.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P57_S0	UGA is party to a marketing agent agreement, dated as of February 15, 2008, as amended from time to time, with the Marketing Agent and USCF, whereby the Marketing Agent provides certain marketing services for UGA as outlined in the agreement.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P57_S1	The fee of the Marketing Agent, which is borne by USCF, is equal to 0.06% on UGA s assets up to $3 billion; and 0.04% on UGA s assets in excess of $3 billion.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P57_S2	In no event may the aggregate compensation paid to the Marketing Agent and any affiliate of USCF for distribution related services exceed ten percent (10%) of the gross proceeds of UGA s offering.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P58_S0	The above fee does not include website construction and development, which are also borne by USCF.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P59_S0	UGA is also party to a custodian agreement, dated January 16, 2008, as amended from time to time, with Brown Brothers Harriman Co. ( BBH Co. ) and USCF, whereby BBH Co. holds investments on behalf of UGA.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P59_S1	USCF pays the fees of the custodian, which are determined by the parties from time to time.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P59_S2	In addition, UGA is party to an administrative agency agreement, dated February 7, 2008, as amended from time to time, with USCF and BBH Co., whereby BBH Co. acts as the administrative agent, transfer agent and registrar for UGA.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P59_S3	USCF also pays the fees of BBH Co. for its services under such agreement and such fees are determined by the parties from time to time.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P60_S0	Currently, USCF pays BBH Co. for its services, in the foregoing capacities, a minimum amount of $75,000 annually for its custody, fund accounting and fund administration services rendered to UGA and each of the Related Public Funds, as well as a $20,000 annual fee for its transfer agency services.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P60_S1	In addition, USCF pays BBH Co.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P60_S2	an asset-based charge of (a) 0.06% for the first $500 million of the Related Public Funds combined net assets, (b) 0.0465% for the Related Public Funds combined net assets greater than $500 million but less than $1 billion, and (c) 0.035% once the Related Public Funds combined net assets exceed $1 billion.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P60_S3	The annual minimum amount will not apply if the asset-based charge for all accounts in the aggregate exceeds $75,000.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P60_S4	USCF also pays BBH Co. transaction fees ranging from $7 to $15 per transaction.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P61_S0	On October 8, 2013, UGA entered into a brokerage agreement with RBC Capital Markets, LLC ( RBC Capital or RBC ) to serve as UGA s FCM effective October 10, 2013.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P61_S1	The agreement with RBC requires it to provide services to UGA in connection with the purchase and sale of Futures Contracts and Other Gasoline-Related Investments that may be purchased and sold by or through RBC Capital for UGA s account.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P61_S2	In accordance with the agreement, RBC Capital charges UGA commissions of approximately $7 to $8 per round-turn trade, including applicable exchange and NFA fees for Futures Contracts and options on Futures Contracts.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P61_S3	Such fees include those incurred when purchasing Futures Contracts and options on Futures Contracts when UGA issues shares as a result of a Creation Basket, as well as fees incurred when selling Futures Contracts and options on Futures Contracts when UGA redeems shares as a result of a Redemption Basket.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P61_S4	Such fees are also incurred when Futures Contracts and options on Futures Contracts are purchased or redeemed for the purpose of rebalancing the portfolio.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P62_S0	UGA also incurs commissions to brokers for the purchase and sale of Futures Contracts, Other Gasoline-Related Investments or short-term obligations of the United States of two years or less ( Treasuries ).
1396878_17_ITEM8_P63_S0	The increase in total commissions accrued to brokers was due primarily to a larger number of futures contracts held and traded during the year ended December 31, 2016, as compared to the year ended December 31, 2015.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P63_S1	The increase in total commissions accrued to brokers for the year ended December 31, 2015 as compared to the year ended December 31, 2014, was primarily due to a larger number of futures contracts held and traded.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P63_S2	However, there can be no assurance that commission costs and portfolio turnover will not cause commission expenses to rise in future quarters.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P64_S0	UGA and the NYMEX entered into a licensing agreement on April 10, 2006, as amended on October 20, 2011, whereby UGA was granted a non-exclusive license to use certain of the NYMEX s settlement prices and service marks.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P64_S1	Under the licensing agreement, UGA and the Related Public Funds, other than BNO, USCI, CPER and USAG, pay the NYMEX an asset-based fee for the license, the terms of which are described in Note 3.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P64_S2	UGA expressly disclaims any association with the NYMEX or endorsement of UGA by the NYMEX and acknowledges that NYMEX and New York Mercantile Exchange are registered trademarks of the NYMEX.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P65_S0	UGA may engage in the trading of futures contracts, options on futures contracts and swaps (collectively, derivatives ).
1396878_17_ITEM8_P65_S1	UGA is exposed to both market risk, which is the risk arising from changes in the market value of the contracts, and credit risk, which is the risk of failure by another party to perform according to the terms of a contract.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P66_S0	UGA may enter into futures contracts, options on futures contracts and swaps to gain exposure to changes in the value of an underlying commodity.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P67_S0	A futures contract obligates the seller to deliver (and the purchaser to accept) the future delivery of a specified quantity and type of a commodity at a specified time and place.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P67_S1	Some futures contracts may call for physical delivery of the asset, while others are settled in cash.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P67_S2	The contractual obligations of a buyer or seller may generally be satisfied by taking or making physical delivery of the underlying commodity or by making an offsetting sale or purchase of an identical futures contract on the same or linked exchange before the designated date of delivery.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P68_S0	Cleared swaps are agreements that are eligible to be cleared by a clearinghouse, e.g., ICE Clear Europe, and provide the efficiencies and benefits that centralized clearing on an exchange offers to traders of futures contracts, including credit risk intermediation and the ability to offset positions initiated with different counterparties.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P69_S0	The purchase and sale of futures contracts, options on futures contracts and swaps require margin deposits with an FCM.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P69_S1	Additional deposits may be necessary for any loss on contract value.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P70_S0	The Commodity Exchange Act requires an FCM to segregate all customer transactions and assets from the FCM s proprietary activities.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P71_S0	Futures contracts, options on futures contracts and swaps involve, to varying degrees, elements of market risk (specifically commodity price risk) and exposure to loss in excess of the amount of variation margin.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P71_S1	The face or contract amounts reflect the extent of the total exposure UGA has in the particular classes of instruments.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P72_S0	Additional risks associated with the use of futures contracts are an imperfect correlation between movements in the price of the futures contracts and the market value of the underlying securities and the possibility of an illiquid market for a futures contract.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P73_S0	Buying and selling options on futures contracts exposes investors to the risks of purchasing or selling futures contracts.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P74_S0	All of the futures contracts held by UGA through December 31, 2016 were exchange-traded.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P74_S1	The risks associated with exchange-traded contracts are generally perceived to be less than those associated with OTC swaps since, in OTC swaps, a party must rely solely on the credit of its respective individual counterparties.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P74_S2	However, in the future, if UGA were to enter into non-exchange traded contracts, it would be subject to the credit risk associated with counterparty non-performance.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P74_S3	The credit risk from counterparty non-performance associated with such instruments is the net unrealized gain, if any, on the transaction.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P75_S0	UGA has credit risk under its futures contracts since the sole counterparty to all domestic and foreign futures contracts is the clearinghouse for the exchange on which the relevant contracts are traded.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P75_S1	In addition, UGA bears the risk of financial failure by the clearing broker.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P76_S0	UGA s cash and other property, such as Treasuries, deposited with an FCM are considered commingled with all other customer funds, subject to the FCM s segregation requirements.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P76_S1	In the event of an FCM s insolvency, recovery may be limited to a pro rata share of segregated funds available.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P76_S2	It is possible that the recovered amount could be less than the total of cash and other property deposited.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P76_S3	The insolvency of an FCM could result in the complete loss of UGA s assets posted with that FCM; however, the majority of UGA s assets are held in investments in Treasuries, cash and/or cash equivalents with UGA s custodian and would not be impacted by the insolvency of an FCM.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P76_S4	The failure or insolvency of UGA s custodian, however, could result in a substantial loss of UGA s assets.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P77_S0	USCF invests a portion of UGA s cash in money market funds that seek to maintain a stable per share NAV.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P77_S1	UGA is exposed to any risk of loss associated with an investment in such money market funds.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P77_S2	As of December 31, 2016 and December 31, 2015, UGA held investments in money market funds in the amounts of $10,000,000 and $22,000,000, respectively.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P77_S3	UGA also holds cash deposits with its custodian.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P78_S0	Pursuant to a written agreement with BBH Co., uninvested overnight cash balances are swept to offshore branches of U.S. regulated and domiciled banks located in Toronto, Canada, London, United Kingdom, Grand Cayman, Cayman Islands and Nassau, Bahamas, which are subject to U.S. regulation and regulatory oversight.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P79_S0	As of December 31, 2016 and December 31, 2015, UGA held cash deposits and investments in Treasuries in the amounts of $56,497,093 and $53,519,309, respectively, with the custodian and FCM.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P79_S1	Some or all of these amounts may be subject to loss should UGA s custodian and/or FCM cease operations.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P80_S0	For derivatives, risks arise from changes in the market value of the contracts.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P80_S1	Theoretically, UGA is exposed to market risk equal to the value of futures contracts purchased and unlimited liability on such contracts sold short.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P80_S2	As both a buyer and a seller of options, UGA pays or receives a premium at the outset and then bears the risk of unfavorable changes in the price of the contract underlying the option.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P81_S0	UGA s policy is to continuously monitor its exposure to market and counterparty risk through the use of a variety of financial, position and credit exposure reporting controls and procedures.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P81_S1	In addition, UGA has a policy of requiring review of the credit standing of each broker or counterparty with which it conducts business.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P82_S0	The financial instruments held by UGA are reported in its statements of financial condition at market or fair value, or at carrying amounts that approximate fair value, because of their highly liquid nature and short-term maturity.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P83_S0	The following table presents per share performance data and other supplemental financial data for the years ended December 31, 2016, 2015 and 2014.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P83_S1	This information has been derived from information presented in the financial statements.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P84_S0	Total returns are calculated based on the change in value during the period.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P84_S1	An individual shareholder s total return and ratio may vary from the above total returns and ratios based on the timing of contributions to and withdrawals from UGA.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P85_S0	The following summarized (unaudited) quarterly financial information presents the results of operations and other data for three-month periods ended March 31, June 30, September 30 and December 31, 2016 and 2015.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P86_S0	UGA values its investments in accordance with Accounting Standards Codification 820 Fair Value Measurements and Disclosures ( ASC 820 ).
1396878_17_ITEM8_P86_S1	ASC 820 defines fair value, establishes a framework for measuring fair value in generally accepted accounting principles, and expands disclosures about fair value measurement.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P86_S2	The changes to past practice resulting from the application of ASC 820 relate to the definition of fair value, the methods used to measure fair value, and the expanded disclosures about fair value measurement.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P87_S0	ASC 820 establishes a fair value hierarchy that distinguishes between: (1) market participant assumptions developed based on market data obtained from sources independent of UGA (observable inputs) and (2) UGA s own assumptions about market participant assumptions developed based on the best information available under the circumstances (unobservable inputs).
1396878_17_ITEM8_P87_S1	The three levels defined by the ASC 820 hierarchy are as follows:
1396878_17_ITEM8_P88_S0	Level I Quoted prices (unadjusted) in active markets for identical assets or liabilities that the reporting entity has the ability to access at the measurement date.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P89_S0	Level II Inputs other than quoted prices included within Level I that are observable for the asset or liability, either directly or indirectly.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P89_S1	Level II assets include the following: quoted prices for similar assets or liabilities in active markets, quoted prices for identical or similar assets or liabilities in markets that are not active, inputs other than quoted prices that are observable for the asset or liability, and inputs that are derived principally from or corroborated by observable market data by correlation or other means (market-corroborated inputs).
1396878_17_ITEM8_P90_S0	Level III Unobservable pricing input at the measurement date for the asset or liability.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P90_S1	Unobservable inputs shall be used to measure fair value to the extent that observable inputs are not available.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P91_S0	In some instances, the inputs used to measure fair value might fall within different levels of the fair value hierarchy.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P91_S1	The level in the fair value hierarchy within which the fair value measurement in its entirety falls shall be determined based on the lowest input level that is significant to the fair value measurement in its entirety.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P92_S0	The following table summarizes the valuation of UGA s securities at December 31, 2016 using the fair value hierarchy:
1396878_17_ITEM8_P93_S0	During the year ended December 31, 2016, there were no transfers between Level I and Level II.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P94_S0	The following table summarizes the valuation of UGA s securities at December 31, 2015 using the fair value hierarchy:
1396878_17_ITEM8_P95_S0	During the year ended December 31, 2015, there were no transfers between Level I and Level II.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P96_S0	Effective January 1, 2009, UGA adopted the provisions of Accounting Standards Codification 815 Derivatives and Hedging, which require presentation of qualitative disclosures about objectives and strategies for using derivatives, quantitative disclosures about fair value amounts and gains and losses on derivatives.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P97_S0	In August 2015, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ( FASB ) issued Accounting Standard Update ( ASU ) 2015-14, Revenue from Contracts with Customers, modifying ASU 2014-09.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P98_S0	The core principle of the guidance is that an entity should recognize revenue to depict the transfer of promised goods or services to customers in an amount that reflects the consideration to which the entity expects to be entitled in exchange for those goods or services.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P99_S0	ASU 2015-14 is effective for fiscal years beginning on or after December 15, 2016, and interim periods within those annual periods.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P99_S1	At this time, management does not believe there will be any impact to the Fund s financial statements.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P100_S0	UGA has performed an evaluation of subsequent events through the date the financial statements were issued.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P100_S1	This evaluation did not result in any subsequent events that necessitated disclosures and/or adjustments.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P101_S0	We have audited the accompanying statements of financial condition of United States Commodity Funds LLC (the Company ) as of December 31, 2016 and 2015.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P101_S1	The Company s management is responsible for these financial statements.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P101_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these financial statements based on our audits.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P102_S0	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1396878_17_ITEM8_P102_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audits to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P102_S2	The Company is not required to have, nor were we engaged to perform, an audit of its internal control over financial reporting.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P102_S3	Our audits included consideration of internal control over financial reporting as a basis for designing audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P102_S4	Accordingly, we express no such opinion.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P103_S0	An audit also includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements, assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P104_S0	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P105_S0	In our opinion, the financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of United States Commodity Funds LLC as of December 31, 2016 and 2015 in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P106_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of these statements of financial condition.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P107_S0	In May 2005, United States Commodity Funds, LLC ( USCF or the Company ), a wholly-owned subsidiary of Wainwright Holdings Inc. ( Wainwright ), was formed as a single member limited liability company in the State of Delaware.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P107_S1	On December 9, 2016, Wainwright was acquired by Concierge Technologies, Inc., ( Concierge ) a public company ( CNCG ) currently traded on the OTC Markets QB Exchange with majority ownership held by two shareholders who also are majority owners of Wainwright.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P107_S2	CNCG will continue to operate USCF as an independent wholly-owned subsidiary of Wainwright.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P107_S3	USCF will also maintain its current independent and management director structure.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P108_S0	USCF is a registered commodity pool operator with the Commodity Futures Trading Commission ( CFTC ) and a member of the National Futures Association ( NFA ) and serves as the General Partner ( General Partner ) for various limited partnerships ( LP ) as noted below.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P109_S0	The Company s operating activities consist primarily of providing management services to eleven public funds.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P110_S0	The Company is currently the General Partner in the following Securities Act of 1933 LP commodity based index funds and Sponsor ( Sponsor ) for the fund series within the United States Commodity Index Funds Trust ( USCIF Trust ):
1396878_17_ITEM8_P111_S0	The USCIF Trust currently has a new fund, USCF Canadian Crude Oil Index Fund ( UCCO ), in registration.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P111_S1	In addition, USCF is the sponsor of the USCF Funds Trust, a Delaware statutory trust, and each of its series, the REX S P MLP Fund, the REX S P MLP Inverse Fund, the United States 3X Oil Fund and the United States 3X Short Oil Fund, all of which are funds that are currently in registration and have not commenced operations.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P111_S2	All USCF funds are collectively referred to as the Funds hereafter.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P112_S0	The accompanying statements of financial condition of the Company have been prepared on the accrual basis of accounting in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America ( U.S. GAAP ).
1396878_17_ITEM8_P113_S0	The preparation of financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities, the disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements, and the reported amounts of revenue and expenses during the reporting period.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P113_S1	Actual results could differ from those estimates.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P114_S0	The Company recognizes revenue under the Funds respective Limited Partnership Agreements, as amended from time to time (the Limited Partnership Agreements ) and the Trust Agreement, as amended from time to time (the Trust Agreement ).
1396878_17_ITEM8_P114_S1	These Agreements provide for fees based upon a percentage of the daily average net asset value of the Funds.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P115_S0	The Company is responsible for investing the assets of the Funds in accordance with the objectives and policies of the respective Funds.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P115_S1	In addition, The Company has arranged for one or more third parties to provide administrative, custody, accounting, transfer agency and other necessary services to the Funds and is contractually obligated to pay for these services.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P116_S0	The Funds are contractually obligated to pay the Company a management fee, which is paid monthly, based on the average daily net assets of the Funds.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P117_S0	USO pays a management fee of 0.45% (45 basis points) per annum on its average daily net assets.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P117_S1	UNG pays a fee equal to 0.60% (60 basis points) per annum on average daily net assets of $1,000,000,000 or less and 0.50% (50 basis points) of average daily net assets that are greater than $1,000,000,000.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P117_S2	USL, UGA, UHN, and DNO each pay a fee of 0.60% (60 basis points) per annum on their average daily net assets.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P117_S3	From inception through April 30, 2010, the Company has been charging UNL a management fee at a reduced rate of 0.60% (60 basis points) per annum of average daily net assets.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P117_S4	Effective May 1, 2010, the Company resumed charging UNL its standard rate of 0.75% (75 basis points) per annum of average daily net assets.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P117_S5	The difference of 0.15% (15 basis points) per annum of average daily net assets since inception through April 30, 2010 has been waived by the Company and will not be recouped from UNL.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P117_S6	BNO pays a management fee of 0.75% (75 basis points) per annum on its average daily net assets.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P118_S0	Effective January 1, 2014 and continuing through December 31, 2015, the Company contractually agreed to lower the management fee for USCI to 0.80% (80 basis points), 0.65% (65 basis points) for CPER and 0.65% (65 basis points) for USAG, per annum on its average daily net assets.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P118_S1	Effective January 1, 2016, the Company permanently lowered the management fee to 0.80% (80 basis points) for USCI, 0.65% (65 basis points) for CPER and 0.65% (65 basis points) for USAG, per annum on its average daily net assets.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P119_S0	Management fees are recognized in the period earned in accordance with the terms of their respective agreements.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P120_S0	The Company has voluntarily agreed to pay certain expenses normally borne by UGA, UHN, DNO, UNL, BNO, CPER and USAG to the extent such expenses exceed 0.15% (15 basis points) of the respective fund s average daily net assets, on an annualized basis.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P120_S1	The Company has no obligation to continue such payments into subsequent periods.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P120_S2	These expenses totaled $939,385 and $760,973 for the years ended December 31, 2016 and 2015 , respectively, and are included in general and administrative expense.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P120_S3	Expense waivers payable totaled $939,385 and $760,973 as of December 31, 2016 and 2015 , respectively.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P121_S0	The Company expenses all startup expenses associated with the registration of each fund and the expense is charged to general and administrative expense.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P121_S1	Fund startup expenses include costs relating to the initial registration of shares and include, but are not limited to, legal fees pertaining to the initial registration of shares, SEC and FINRA registration fees, initial fees to be listed on an exchange, and other similar costs.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P122_S0	The Funds pay for all brokerage fees, taxes and other expenses, including registration or other fees paid to the SEC, the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority ( FINRA ) formerly the National Association of Securities Dealers, or any other regulatory agency in connection with the offer and sale of subsequent shares after their initial registration and all legal, accounting, printing and other expenses associated therewith.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P123_S0	The Company considers all highly liquid investments with original maturities of three months or less at the date of purchase to be cash equivalents.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P123_S1	The Company places its cash with various high credit quality institutions.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P123_S2	At times, the Company maintains cash deposits in excess of the United States Federal Deposit Corporation coverage of $250,000, but the Company does not expect any losses.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P124_S0	Management fees receivable generally consist of one month of management fees which are collected in the month after they are earned.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P125_S0	Management closely monitors receivables and records an allowance for any balances that are determined to be uncollectible.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P125_S1	As of December 31, 2016 and 2015 , the Company considered all remaining accounts receivable to be fully collectible.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P126_S0	Management determines the appropriate classification of investments at the time of purchase based upon management s intent with respect to such investments.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P127_S0	Short-term investments consist of equities and money market funds.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P127_S1	Short-term investments are classified as available-for-sale securities.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P127_S2	The Company measures the investments at estimated fair value at period end with any changes in estimated fair value reflected as unrealized gains (losses) in the accumulated other comprehensive income (loss).
1396878_17_ITEM8_P128_S0	The Company reports all changes in equity during the year, except those resulting from investment by its member and distributions to its member, in the year in which they are recognized.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P129_S0	Comprehensive income is the total of net income (loss) and other comprehensive income (loss).
1396878_17_ITEM8_P129_S1	The Company recognized $75 of other comprehensive income and $707 of other comprehensive loss in 2016 and 2015, respectively, related to changes in unrealized losses on investments.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P130_S0	The Company s short-term investments are carried at estimated fair value.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P130_S1	In determining fair value, the Company follows the guidance of Financial Accounting Standards Board ( FASB ) Accounting Standards Codification ( ASC ) 820, Fair Value Measurement ( ASC 820 ).
1396878_17_ITEM8_P130_S2	Under ASC 820, the fair value is defined as the price that would be received upon the sale of an asset or paid to transfer a liability (i.e., the exit price) in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P131_S0	ASC 820 establishes a fair value hierarchy based on the lowest level input that is significant to the fair value measurement in its entirety:
1396878_17_ITEM8_P132_S0	Level 1 Quoted prices in active markets that are accessible at the measurement date for identical, unrestricted assets or liabilities, without adjustment.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P133_S0	Level 2 Quoted prices in markets that are not considered to be active for identical or similar assets or liabilities, quoted prices in active markets of similar assets or liabilities, and inputs other than quoted prices that are observable or can be corroborated by observable market data.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P134_S0	Level 3 Pricing inputs are unobservable and include situations where there is little, if any, market activity for the investment.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P135_S0	Unrealized gains and losses on investments resulting from market fluctuations are recorded in the accumulated other comprehensive income (loss) account.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P136_S0	Realized gains or losses on sales of investments determined on a specific identification basis.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P137_S0	All short-term investments, which include money market funds and equities, are classified as Level 1 investments at December 31, 2016 and 2015 .
1396878_17_ITEM8_P137_S1	The Company has no Level 2 and 3 investments.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P137_S2	There were no transfers between levels during the years ended December 31, 2016 and 2015 .
1396878_17_ITEM8_P138_S0	Short-term investments are valued at the closing price reported on the active market on which the individual securities are traded.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P139_S0	The Company has filed an election with the Internal Revenue Service to be treated as an association taxable as a corporation.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P139_S1	The Company files a federal consolidated income tax return with entities not included on these financials.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P139_S2	In connection with filing a consolidated federal income tax return, the tax benefit of utilizing tax losses generated by the consolidated group is not reflected on USCF s statements of financial condition.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P140_S0	The Company accounts for income taxes using the asset and liability method.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P140_S1	Under this method, deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the future tax consequences attributable to differences between financial statement carrying amounts of existing assets and liabilities and their respective tax bases, valuation of net operating losses and tax credit carryforwards, if any.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P141_S0	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured using enacted rates expected to apply to taxable income in the years in which those temporary differences are expected to be recovered or settled.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P141_S1	If necessary, a valuation allowance is recorded to reduce the carrying amounts of deferred tax assets until it is more likely than not that such assets will be realized.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P142_S0	The Company provides for uncertain tax positions using guidance which prescribes a recognition threshold and measurement attribute for the financial statement recognition and measurement of a tax position taken or expected to be taken in a tax return.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P142_S1	It provides that a tax benefit from an uncertain tax position may be recognized when it is more-likely-than-not recognition threshold at the effective date to be recognized upon the adoption of the accounting standard and in subsequent periods.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P142_S2	In addition, the accounting standard provides guidance on derecognition, classification, interest and penalties, accounting in interim periods, disclosure and transition.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P142_S3	The Company s policy is to recognize interest and penalties accrued on any unrecognized tax benefits as a component of income tax expense.

1396878_17_ITEM8_P144_S0	No. 2016-01, Recognition and Measurement of Financial Assets and Financial Liabilities , to mainly change the accounting for investments in equity securities and financial liabilities carried at fair value as well as to modify the presentation and disclosure requirements for financial instruments.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P144_S1	The ASU is effective for annual periods beginning after December 15, 2018, with early adoption permitted.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P144_S2	Adoption of the ASU is retrospective with a cumulative adjustment to retained earnings or accumulated deficit as of the adoption date.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P144_S3	The Company does not anticipate that the adoption of the ASU will have a material impact on its financial statements.

1396878_17_ITEM8_P145_S1	The guidance in ASU No. 2016-02 supersedes the lease recognition requirements in ASC Topic 840, Leases (FAS 13) .
1396878_17_ITEM8_P145_S2	ASU 2016-02 requires an entity to recognize assets and liabilities arising from a lease for both financing and operating leases, along with additional qualitative and quantitative disclosures.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P145_S3	ASU 2016-02 is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2018, with early adoption permitted.

1396878_17_ITEM8_P153_S0	The Company has filed an election with the Internal Revenue Service to be treated as an association taxable as a corporation.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P153_S1	The Company files a federal consolidated income tax return with entities not included on these financials.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P153_S2	In connection with filing a consolidated federal income tax return, the tax benefit of utilizing tax losses generated by the consolidated group is not reflected on USCF s statements of financial condition.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P153_S3	In connection with filing a consolidated federal income tax return, the Company has recorded federal income tax expense and deferred tax assets at the legal entity level as if it was filing its own stand-alone taxes.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P154_S0	Deferred tax assets and liabilities reflect the net tax effects of temporary differences between the carrying amounts of assets and liabilities for financial reporting purposes and the amounts used for income tax purposes.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P154_S1	Significant components of the Company s deferred tax assets as of December 31, 2016 and 2015 are as follows:
1396878_17_ITEM8_P155_S0	The majority of the deferred tax assets relate to startup costs associated with the organization and registration of the Funds for which the Company is a general partner and having paid such costs.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P156_S0	Realization of the deferred tax assets is dependent upon future taxable income, if any, the amount and timing of which is uncertain.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P156_S1	Based upon available objective evidence, management believes it is more likely than not that the net deferred tax assets will not be fully realizable for capital loss carryover.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P156_S2	Accordingly, management has established a valuation allowance related to this deferred tax asset.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P156_S3	The valuation allowance decreased by approximately $13,000 during 2016 and $0 during 2015.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P156_S4	The change in the valuation allowance is due to the expiration of the deferred tax asset for capital loss carryover.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P157_S0	The Company is subject to income taxes in the U.S. federal jurisdiction and various state jurisdictions.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P157_S1	Tax regulations within each jurisdiction are subject to the interpretation of the related tax laws and regulations and require significant judgment to apply.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P157_S2	The Company s tax years 2012 through 2016 will remain open for examination by the federal and state authorities for three and four years, respectively.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P157_S3	As of December 31, 2016, there were no active taxing authority examinations.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P158_S0	The Company had unrecognized tax benefits ( UTBs ) of approximately $29,000 and $15,000 as of December 31, 2016 and 2015, respectively, which would affect the effective tax rate if recognized before consideration of the valuation allowance.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P158_S1	The Company will recognize interest and penalties, when they occur, related to uncertain tax provisions as a component of tax expense.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P158_S2	There is no interest or penalties to be recognized for the years ended December 31, 2016 and 2015.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P158_S3	The Company does not expect its UTBs to change significantly over the next 12 months.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P159_S0	The Funds are deemed by management to be related parties.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P159_S1	The Company s revenues, totaling $25,425,892 and $21,716,866 for the years ended December 31, 2016 and 2015 , respectively, were earned from these related parties.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P159_S2	Accounts receivable, totaling $2,199,866 and $1,933,672 as of December 31, 2016 and 2015 , respectively, were owed from these relate parties.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P159_S3	Expense waivers, totaling $939,385 and $760,973 for the years ended December 31, 2016 and 2015 , respectively, were incurred on behalf of these related parties.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P159_S4	Waivers payable, totaling $939,385 and $760,973 as of December 31, 2016 and 2015, respectively, were owed to these related parties.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P160_S0	During the years ended December 31, 2016 and 2015, the Company paid $2,100,000 and $5,576,099, respectively, in distributions to its member Wainwright.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P160_S1	As of December 31, 2016, the Company approved an additional dividend of $2,000,000 payable to Wainwright which was paid in January 2017.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P161_S0	On January 14, 2015, Wainwright entered into a stock repurchase agreement as part of an employment separation agreement with one of its shareholders.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P161_S1	The agreement called for Wainwright to purchase the shareholder s stock for $4,389,066.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P161_S2	The payments were made from funds from the Company s distribution payments to its member parent company, Wainwright.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P161_S3	The total repurchase amount was paid by July 15, 2015.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P162_S0	The Company files a federal consolidated income tax return with entities not included on these financials.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P162_S1	In connection with filing a consolidated federal income tax return, the tax benefit of utilizing tax losses generated by the consolidated group is not reflected on USCF s statements of financial condition.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P162_S2	The Company s taxes are computed as if it files on a stand-alone basis (see Note 6).
1396878_17_ITEM8_P163_S0	The Company evaluated subsequent events for recognition and disclosure through February 24, 2017, the date the statements of financial condition were issued or filed.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P163_S1	Nothing has occurred outside normal operations since that required recognition or disclosure in these statements of financial condition other than the items noted below.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P164_S0	On January 6, 2017, the Company paid a $2,000,000 dividend to Wainwright.
1396878_17_ITEM8_P165_S0	On February 16, 2017, the Company approved a $2,500,000 dividend to Wainwright.
1396878_17_ITEM9A_P0_S0	UGA maintains disclosure controls and procedures that are designed to ensure that information required to be disclosed in UGA s periodic reports filed or submitted under the Exchange Act of 1934 is recorded, processed, summarized and reported within the time period specified in the SEC s rules and forms.
1396878_17_ITEM9A_P1_S0	The duly appointed officers of USCF, including its chief executive officer and chief financial officer, who perform functions equivalent to those of a principal executive officer and principal financial officer of UGA if UGA had any officers, have evaluated the effectiveness of UGA s disclosure controls and procedures and have concluded that the disclosure controls and procedures of UGA have been effective as of the end of the period covered by this annual report on Form 10-K.
1396878_17_ITEM9A_P2_S0	UGA is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting.
1396878_17_ITEM9A_P2_S1	UGA s internal control system is designed to provide reasonable assurance to USCF and the Board of USCF regarding the preparation and fair presentation of published financial statements.
1396878_17_ITEM9A_P2_S2	All internal control systems, no matter how well designed, have inherent limitations.
1396878_17_ITEM9A_P2_S3	Therefore, even those systems determined to be effective can provide only reasonable assurance with respect to financial statement preparation and presentation.
1396878_17_ITEM9A_P3_S0	USCF s report on internal control over financial reporting is set forth above under the heading, Management s Annual Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting in Item 8 of this annual report on Form 10-K.
1396878_17_ITEM9A_P4_S0	There were no changes in UGA s internal control over financial reporting during UGA s last fiscal quarter that have materially affected, or are reasonably likely to materially affect, UGA s internal control over financial reporting.
1396878_17_ITEM9B_P0_S0	Pursuant to the requirement under Rule 4.22 under the CEA, each month UGA publishes an account statement for its shareholders, which includes a Statement of Income (Loss) and a Statement of Changes in Net Asset Value.
1396878_17_ITEM9B_P0_S1	The account statement is furnished to the SEC on a current report on Form 8-K pursuant to Section 13 or 15(d) of the Exchange Act and posted each month on UGA s website at www.uscfinvestments.com.

1396878_17_ITEM10_P33_S0	He earned an MBA from the Stanford University Graduate School of Business, graduated from Oxford University in 1982 after studying politics, philosophy, and economics and graduated summa cum laude from Dartmouth College in 1979.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P34_S0	The following are individual Principals, as that term is defined in CFTC Rule 3.1, for USCF: John P. Love, Stuart P. Crumbaugh, Nicholas D. Gerber, Andrew Ngim, Robert Nguyen, Peter Robinson, Gordon Ellis, Malcolm Fobes, Ray Allen, Kevin Baum, Carolyn Yu and Wainwright Holdings Inc.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P34_S1	The individuals who are Principals due to their positions are John P. Love, Stuart P. Crumbaugh, Nicholas D. Gerber, Andrew Ngim, Robert Nguyen, Peter Robinson, Gordon Ellis, Malcolm Fobes, Ray Allen, Kevin Baum and Carolyn Yu.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P34_S2	In addition, Wainwright is a Principal because it is the sole member of USCF.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P34_S3	None of the Principals owns or has any other beneficial interest in UGA.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P35_S0	Ray Allen and John P. Love make trading and investment decisions for UGA.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P36_S0	John P. Love and Ray Allen execute trades on behalf of UGA.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P36_S1	In addition, Nicholas D. Gerber, John P. Love, Robert Nguyen, and Ray Allen and Kevin Baum are registered with the CFTC as Associated Persons of USCF and are NFA Associate Members.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P36_S2	John P. Love, Robert Nguyen, Ray Allen and Kevin Baum are also registered with the CFTC as Swaps Associated Persons.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P37_S0	The Board of USCF has an audit committee which is made up of the three independent directors (Gordon L. Ellis, Malcolm R. Fobes III, and Peter M. Robinson).
1396878_17_ITEM10_P37_S1	The audit committee is governed by an audit committee charter that is posted on UGA s website at www.uscfinvestments.com.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P37_S2	Any shareholder of UGA may also obtain a printed copy of the audit committee charter, free of charge, by calling 1-800-920-0259.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P38_S0	The Board has determined that each member of the audit committee meets the financial literacy requirements of the NYSE Arca and the audit committee charter.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P38_S1	The Board has further determined that each of Messrs. Ellis and Fobes have accounting or related financial management expertise, as required by the NYSE Arca, such that each of them is considered an Audit Committee Financial Expert as such term is defined in Item 407(d)(5) of Regulation S-K.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P39_S0	Since the individuals who perform work on behalf of UGA are not compensated by UGA, but instead by USCF, UGA does not have a compensation committee.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P39_S1	Similarly, since the directors noted above serve on the Board of USCF, there is no nominating committee of the Board that acts on behalf of UGA.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P40_S0	USCF believes that it is necessary for each member of the Board to possess many qualities and skills.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P40_S1	USCF further believes that all directors should possess a considerable amount of business management and educational experience.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P41_S0	When vacancies in USCF s Board occur, the members of the Board consider a candidate s management experience as well as his/her background, stature, conflicts of interest, integrity and ethics.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P41_S1	In connection with this, the Board also considers issues of diversity, such as diversity of gender, race and national origin, education, professional experience and differences in viewpoints and skills.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P41_S2	The Board does not have a formal policy with respect to diversity; however, the Board believes that it is essential that the Board members represent diverse viewpoints.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P42_S0	The Board of USCF has adopted a Corporate Governance Policy that applies to UGA and the Related Public Funds.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P42_S1	UGA has posted the text of the Corporate Governance Policy on its website at www.uscfinvestments.com.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P42_S2	Any shareholder of UGA may also obtain a printed copy of the Corporate Governance Policy, free of charge, by calling 1-800-920-0259.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P43_S0	USCF has adopted a Code of Business Conduct and Ethics (the Code of Ethics ) that applies to its principal executive officer, principal financial officer, principal accounting officer or controller, or persons performing similar functions, and also to UGA.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P43_S1	UGA has posted the text of the Code of Ethics on its website at www.uscfinvestments.com.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P43_S2	Any shareholder of UGA may also obtain a printed copy of the Code of Ethics, free of charge, by calling 1-800-920-0259.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P43_S3	UGA intends to disclose any amendments or waivers to the Code of Ethics applicable to USCF s principal executive officer, principal financial officer, principal accounting officer or controller, or persons performing similar functions, on its website.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P44_S0	In accordance with the Corporate Governance Policy of USCF, the non-management directors of the Board (who are the same as the independent directors of the Board) meet separately from the other directors in regularly scheduled executive sessions, without the presence of Management Directors or executive officers of USCF.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P44_S1	The non-management directors have designated Gordon L. Ellis to preside over each such executive session.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P44_S2	Interested parties who wish to make their concerns known to the non-management directors may communicate directly with Mr. Ellis by writing to 475 Milan Drive, No. 103, San Jose, CA 95134-2453 or by e-mail at uscf.director@gmail.com.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P45_S0	The Board of USCF is led by a Chairman, Nicholas Gerber, Mr. John P. Love separately serves as USCF s President and Chief Executive Officer.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P45_S1	The Board s responsibilities include: (i) the selection, evaluation, retention and succession of the Chief Executive Officer and the oversight of the selection and performance of other executive officers, (ii) understanding, reviewing and monitoring the implementation of strategic plans, annual operating plans and budgets, (iii) the selection and oversight of UGA s independent auditors and the oversight of UGA s financial statements, (iv) advising management on significant issues, (v) the review and approval of significant company actions and certain other matters, (vi) nominating directors and committee members and overseeing effective corporate governance and (vii) the consideration of other constituencies, such as USCF s and UGA s customers, employees, suppliers and the communities impacted by UGA.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P45_S2	The non-management directors have designated Gordon L. Ellis as the presiding independent director.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P45_S3	Mr. Ellis role as the presiding independent director includes presiding over each executive session of the non-management directors, facilitating communications by shareholders and employees with the non-management directors and may also include representing the non-management directors with respect to certain matters as to which the views of the non-management directors are sought pursuant to UGA s Corporate Governance Policy.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P46_S0	The Board believes that Mr. Gerber is best situated to serve as Chairman of USCF because he is the director most familiar with the business of USCF as founder of USCF.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P46_S1	Because of his background, he is most capable of effectively leading discussions and execution of new strategic objectives while facilitating information flow between USCF and the full Board, including the independent directors, which is essential to effective governance.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P46_S2	The independent directors of USCF are actively involved in the oversight of USCF and, because of their varied backgrounds, provide different perspectives in connection with the oversight of USCF, UGA and the Related Public Funds.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P46_S3	USCF s independent directors bring expertise from outside USCF and the commodities industry, while Mr. Gerber brings company-specific and industry-specific experience and expertise.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P47_S0	The full Board is actively involved in overseeing the management and operation of USCF, including oversight of the risks that face UGA and the Related Public Funds.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P47_S1	For example, the Board has adopted an Investment Policy and a Policy for Use of Derivatives.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P47_S2	The policies are intended to ensure that USCF takes prudent and careful action while entering into and managing investments taken by UGA, including Futures Contracts or Other Gasoline-Related Investments such as OTC swap contracts.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P47_S3	Additionally, the policies are intended to provide assurance that there is sufficient flexibility in controlling risks and returns associated with the use of investments by UGA.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P47_S4	The policies, among other things, limit UGA s ability to have too high of a concentration of its assets in non-exchange traded futures contracts or cleared swap contracts or concentrating its investments in too few counterparties, absent prior approval from the Board.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P47_S5	Existing counterparties are reviewed periodically by the Board to ensure that they continue to meet the criteria outlined in the policies.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P48_S0	The Board tasks USCF with assessing risks, including market risk, credit risk, liquidity risk, cash flow risk, basis risk, legal and tax risk, settlement risk, and operational risk.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P49_S0	There are certain risks that may arise as a result of a growth in assets under management.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P49_S1	For example, if position limits are imposed on UGA and the assets under management continue to increase, then UGA may not be able to invest solely in the Benchmark Futures Contract and may have to invest in OTC swap contracts or Other Gasoline-Related Investments as it seeks to track its benchmark.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P49_S2	Other Futures Contracts in which UGA may invest may not track changes in the price of the Benchmark Futures Contract.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P49_S3	Other Gasoline-Related Investments, including OTC swap contracts, may also expose UGA to increased counterparty credit risk and may be less liquid and more difficult to value than Futures Contracts.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P49_S4	UGA and the Related Public Funds ameliorate the potential credit, liquidity and valuation risks by fully collateralizing any OTC swap contracts or other investments.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P50_S0	In addition to the certifications of the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer of USCF filed or furnished with this annual report on Form 10-K regarding the quality of UGA s public disclosure, UGA will submit, within 30 days after filing this annual report on Form 10-K, to the NYSE Arca a certification of the Chief Executive Officer of USCF certifying that he is not aware of any violation by UGA of NYSE Arca corporate governance listing standards.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P51_S0	Section 16(a) of the Exchange Act requires directors and executive officers of USCF and persons who are beneficial owners of at least 10% of UGA s shares to file with the SEC an Initial Statement of Beneficial Ownership of Securities on Form 3 within 10 calendar days of first becoming a director, executive officer or beneficial owner of at least 10% of UGA s shares and a Statement of Changes of Beneficial Ownership of Securities on Form 4 within 2 business days of a subsequent acquisition or disposition of shares of UGA.
1396878_17_ITEM10_P51_S1	To UGA s knowledge, based upon a review of copies of reports furnished to it with respect to the fiscal year ended December 31, 2016 and upon the written representations of the directors and executive officers of USCF, all of such persons have filed all required reports.

1396878_17_ITEM11_P0_S2	UGA does not reimburse USCF for, nor does it set the amount or form of any portion of, the compensation paid to the executive officers by USCF.
1396878_17_ITEM11_P0_S3	UGA pays fees to USCF pursuant to the LP Agreement under which it is obligated to pay USCF an annualized fee of 0.60% of its average daily net assets.

1396878_17_ITEM13_P3_S0	In February 2016, the Board undertook a review of the independence of the directors of USCF and considered whether any director has a material relationship or other arrangement with USCF, UGA or the Related Public Funds that could compromise his ability to exercise independent judgment in carrying out his responsibilities.
1396878_17_ITEM13_P3_S1	As a result of this review, the Board determined that each of Messrs. Fobes, Ellis and Robinson is an independent director, as defined under the rules of NYSE Arca.
1396878_17_ITEM14_P0_S0	The fees for services billed to UGA by its independent auditors for the last two fiscal years are as follows:

1396878_17_ITEM14_P3_S0	The audit committee has established policies and procedures which are intended to control the services provided by UGA s independent auditors and to monitor their continuing independence.
1396878_17_ITEM14_P3_S1	Under these policies and procedures, no audit or permitted non-audit services (including fees and terms thereof), except for the de minimis exceptions for non-audit services described in Section 10A(i)(1)(B) of the Exchange Act, may be undertaken by UGA s independent auditors unless the engagement is specifically pre-approved by the audit committee.
1396878_17_ITEM14_P4_S0	The audit committee may form and delegate authority to subcommittees consisting of one or more members when appropriate, including the authority to grant pre-approvals of audit and permitted non-audit services, provided that decisions of such subcommittee to grant pre-approvals must be presented to the full audit committee at its next scheduled meeting.
